profile: sound artist and musician
title: The Whistled Valley
description:
The Whistled Valley (2025) is a 20-minute Ambisonic sound composition exploring Silbo Gomero, the whistled language of La Gomera in the Canary Islands. Presented in 3rd-order Ambisonics (16-channel spatial audio), the work is designed for immersive playback in multichannel speaker arrays, inviting audiences to experience the echoes of a vanishing oral tradition.
Developed during a two-week field trip on La Gomera in June 2025, the project combines location recordings, interviews, and participatory listening sessions with Silbo Gomero speakers and educators. These materials, together with the island’s environmental soundscapes, form the basis of the composition.
Structured around poetic narration, fragmented testimonies, and reconstructed acoustic environments, the piece highlights both the affective and archival dimensions of a language at risk. Silbo Gomero is not only a communicative tool but also a sonic marker of cultural identity and intergenerational memory. By embedding its fragile presence within immersive spatial sound, The Whistled Valley invites listeners to engage with the emotional and historical weight of this unique human expression, standing as a call to listen, remember, and protect intangible heritage before it disappears into silence.

Please note: The Whistled Valley was originally composed in a 16-channels Ambisonic format, intended for playback through a dedicated loudspeaker setup to fully reproduce the spatial experience. For accessibility and review purposes, a binaural rendering of the work is provided via the link. This version is for headphone listening only, as it preserves the distinctive spatialisation and immersive qualities of the original multichannel composition.
userBio: Jiaye Wang (*2003) is a sound artist and musician born in China and currently based in London. Her artistic practice spans multichannel spatial sound, sound design, sound installation, and music. As a sound artist, she is particularly interested in exploring the intersections of culture, human experience, and social memory. Drawing on her professional expertise in sound technology, she frequently engages in interdisciplinary collaborations with practitioners in theatre, music, film, and new media.

major: Radio and Television Scriptwriting and Directing
profile: Suhao Zhang(b. 2003), a Jiangsu-born filmmaker and musician, has earned acclaim across film festivals: his solo-directed Tico Tico Life(hybrid docu-fiction) screened at the 19th FIRST International Film Festival’s FIRST PIONEER section, while Frozen Moments, Fading Echoes(Machinima) premiered at FIRST FANTASTIC Film Festival. Earlier, as a sophomore, he co-directed Crossing the Yangtze River, shortlisted for China’s 14th Documentary Academy Awards. His practice dissects body, identity, and societal dynamics through fragmented visuals and ambient sound—eschewing rigid interpretation, he prioritizes raw, sensory immersion to provoke visceral engagement with lived realities.
title: Turned to Stone
description: In reverie, I wander this land where the familiar gnaws at the strange—crowds, smog, ships suspended in time’s amber, neither truly still nor fully adrift. Is this the cradle of my first breath? The scents of youth have long faded from my senses... Perhaps these streets, like my memories, have turned to stone.

profile:
Jiayue Yu is a new media artist. The core of her creative practice lies in visualizing invisible psychological traumas and societal pressures. She excels at using a hybrid digital media language—combining generative art (TouchDesigner), 3D modeling, and aggressive imagery—to explore the internal struggles faced by contemporary individuals.
Her work often originates from deeply personal experiences. In her project "Picky Eater," a visceral dissection of childhood eating trauma, she transforms abstract emotions—such as suffocation, burnout, and disgust—into perceptible, concrete digital forms by creating sensory experiences that are at once familiar and profoundly unsettling. Her work serves not only as a process of personal memory but also as a sharp response to universal human vulnerabilities and systemic issues, aiming to provoke strong emotional resonance and critical thought from the viewer.
title: Picky Eater
description:
Picky Eater is an experimental digital video work that delves into the family power dynamics and psychological trauma stemming from childhood memories of picky eating. Rooted in the artist's personal experience, the work translates the suffocating feeling of a love administered 'for one's own good' and the anguish of being force-fed into a visceral and unsettling audio-visual language.
Through organic visuals generated in TouchDesigner that simulate vomit and decaying food, combined with oppressive family recordings and a distorted soundscape, the work constructs a psychological space poised between memory and nightmare. Within the video, the juxtaposition of cold electronic screens against slick, raw meat symbolizes the conflict between a bodily perception alienated by technology and a primal, visceral revulsion.
Ultimately, Picky Eater is not merely a recollection of personal trauma but a profound interrogation of the blurred boundary between 'love' and 'control.' It compels the viewer to reconsider actions, performed in the name of love, that can inflict intangible harm upon an individual.

profile:
As a fashion designer and artist from China, my creative practice is deeply shaped by the dialogue between Eastern philosophy and Western aesthetics. After completing my BA in Womenswear Design at London College of Fashion in 2024, I continued to explore the intersection of materiality and cultural identity during my Graduate Diploma in Fashion & Textiles at the Royal College of Art in 2025. This journey has now led me back to LCF, where I am pursuing an MA in Fashion Design Management, seeking to expand my understanding of how creative vision can evolve into sustainable systems of value.

My design language emerges from an intuitive conversation between tradition and experimentation. Rooted in my oriental heritage, I often draw from Chinese talismanic symbols, mythic imagery, and natural materials—such as clay, metal, and stone—to create wearable pieces that carry both spiritual and tactile resonance. I see fashion as more than a visual form; it is a vessel of cultural storytelling and emotional energy.

To me, fashion design is like a lotus leaf—anchored in my cultural roots yet freely floating between disciplines, mediums, and meanings. Through this balance of grounding and transcendence, I hope to build a creative practice that bridges the poetic and the practical, the spiritual and the modern.
title: ALL IS ONE
description:
Rooted in the Taoist and Confucian concept of Tian Ren He Yi (天人合一) — the harmony between humanity and nature — this project examines the delicate balance between the natural and the artificial in contemporary life. Drawing on the Five Elements philosophy of metal, wood, water, fire, and earth, the work explores how these forces shape both the physical and spiritual dimensions of existence, continually cycling through creation and decay.

Alongside these classical cosmologies, the project draws inspiration from the animistic traditions of the Bai ethnic group in China, whose nature worship practices emphasise the spiritual vitality of mountains, rivers, and stones. It also incorporates references to Jiama culture — the ritual art of printed talismans used for protection and communication between the human and the divine. By translating these vernacular spiritual symbols into modern design language, the work aims to reenergise their significance in a contemporary, global context.

In today’s technologically accelerated era, where our relationship with nature is increasingly strained, Harmony in Disconnection reimagines how these ancestral philosophies might help us re-evaluate our material and spiritual connection to the natural world. Through the integration of clay, stone, and metal into garment structures and sculptural forms, the work blurs the boundary between the organic and the artificial. Each piece becomes a meditation on coexistence — where material, body, and spirit intertwine, and where ancient ecological wisdom finds new resonance through contemporary fashion practice.

lastName: Liang in collaboration with May Li
profile:
Viola Liang is an AI narrative artist and creative technologist. Her practice explores AI and intimacy through collaborative storytelling, creating folklore and rituals with AI and emerging technologies. Her work invites audiences to engage with generative AI in participatory and speculative environments.  

May Li is a research-based artist whose practice examines how digital systems mediate intimacy and reshape discourse, visibility, and behaviour through speculative design, algorithmic storytelling. Her practice combines AI, digital narratives, and media archaeology to explore suppression and belief. 

Viola and May are collaborating as a duo based in London to push boundaries of AI-driven storytelling and worldbuilding. Both graduated with an MFA in Computational Arts from Goldsmiths, University of London. Their shared interest in digital intimacy led to their residency at Tate, where they showed their practice of co-creating speculative fiction with generative AI, and co-led public workshops exploring AI’s potential to create new forms of narrative.
title: Blessed Market
description:
Blessed Market is an immersive theatrical experience featuring interactive installations and live performances. Designed for two audiences at a time, this 15-20 minute experience is set in a 
fictional market rooted in Chinese speculative folklore. It introduces Vase Girl and Screen Girl, who act as both narrators and AI-driven performers, inviting participant into a spooky environment layered with interaction: exploring the space, talking with characters, choosing how to respond whether through feeding, touching, and offering, or by learning through ritualised tutorials.These interactions shift the experience from passive observation to co-creation, where audience responses actively shape the unfolding story. 

Over eight months of exploration and experimentation, we developed multiple prototypes across concepts, technologies, and fabrication, engaged with audiences through six public showcases, and continuously refined the work based on feedback from diverse participants. Feedback shows emotions build gradually with all elements connected to form continuity. 

Blessed Market stages the intimacy between AI and humans as uncanny and unstable. The two characters speak to participants, embodying fragments of the story world through installations. This creates the illusion of agency, prompting audiences to relate to AI not as mere tools but as beings with their own identities. 
 
This project explores how the unpredictability, anthropomorphism, and surveillance of artificial intelligence reflect dynamics of intimacy and manipulation. It also provokes participants to consider whether the intimacy between AI and humans is a projection of our own desires or the emergence of a new relationship between human and non-human entities.

school: Accademy of fine arts of Bari
profile:
Xiuwen Guan(artistic name: NeReid)was born in China in 1998.
She earned her BA in Painting from the Academy of Fine Arts in Frosinone (2022), and her MFA in Painting – New Trends from the Academy of Fine Arts in Bari (2025).
She currently lives and works in Molfetta, Italy.
Her work blends natural elements (like shells) and female forms in a symbolic-surreal style.
She explores the edge between reality and imagination through still life, dreamscapes, and layered meanings.
She has exhibited in Ferrara, Bari, Terni, Trani, Monopoli in Italy, and held her solo show In the Sea of Memories in Bari in 2023.
title: Empty heart
description: This painting is inspired by the concept of empty-heart illness, the existential anxiety among young people in east asia. For a long time I feel meaningless and helpless, unable to find my way and identity. Just like a shell in the sea carried by waves and winds, shattering and fading slowly by the time.

profile: Zhang Zhiye (b. 2000, Shenzhen), China, holds a Bachelor of Fine Art from Goldsmiths, University of London, and a Master’s degree in Ceramics & Glass from the Royal College of Art. Her practice consistently engages with the role of clay in the construction of nature and mythology, treating it as a hybrid, historically situated, and liminal material within the humanities.
title: The Order
description:
The form of this work originates from the frog worship in Yang-shao culture, reinterpreting and reconstructing mythology in a contemporary, deliberately structured way. Myth is not a static archetype, but something continuously reinvented, appropriated, and projected under changing historical conditions. The image and power of the East Asian creation goddess Nüwa, as civilization shifted toward a patriarchal narrative, became embedded within a kinship and marital framework of mutual dependence with Fuxi—thus, through layers of historical storytelling, the goddess transformed from a frog into a serpent-bodied being.

I chose clay—an ancient material that has endured since prehistory—as the primary medium of narration. It reminds us of the fragility and transience of all stories. I regard the act of creation as both reconstruction and speculation: through the accumulation, repetition, and transformation of clay, new relationships and spaces emerge. Filling and hollowing, imitation and inheritance, extension and deviation occur simultaneously. Like the ancient coiling technique itself, the process comes full circle—returning, at last, to its beginning.

profile: Rosie Hutabarat is a British Indonesian Illustrator and Animator who explores the themes of self-love and the complexities of human emotions, combining elements of both her cultural heritage, as well as traditional and digital textures to create ethereal, thought-provoking imagery. She believes in the importance of finding beauty in the mundane, particularly during times of difficulty. By taking inspiration from the natural world, she creates whimsical concepts that offer moments of serenity and emotional connection with the viewers.
title: Hantu
description:
Hantu (meaning ghost/spirit) is a wordless comic that tells the story of a young girl who goes to watch a traditional Balinese dance troupes’ performance with her father and brother. As she watches the performance, she finds herself transported into an unknown land in which she encounters a mysterious friend who becomes her source of strength and support, helping her to find a way back home.

The comic was inspired by my recent trip to Indonesia where I had the opportunity to reconnect with my family there, teaching me about the countries folklore and stories behind their traditional dances.

profile:
Zhenghan Huang, Photographer, based in London and Shanghai

Han specializes in fashion, portraiture, and still life, encompassing both still and moving images. Her work is characterized by a use of light, shadow, and texture to create captivating scenes that narrate stories of people across different times and places. In her photography, Huang constructs her own memories, capturing the subtle, peaceful, and occasionally melancholic moments of everyday life. Her visual language, rich in nuance, seamlessly blends fashion with elements of daily existence and nature.
title: The Waves Return
description:
Nostalgic narratives that traverse time and place lie at the heart of Zhenghan Huang’s practice.

In The Waves Return, she revisits her childhood holidays by the seaside in her hometown in China and reflects on her more recent experiences along the British coast. Drawing upon early photographs and home videos taken by her parents, Huang reactivates these intimate records as personal archives, vessels of memory where distance and identity quietly intertwine. In Huang’s words, “My mind generates new images from the past. To further explore this dynamic, I returned to the coastal area of my upbringing this past summer.”

The work also touches upon the traces of absence and the fragility of memory. Through rephotography and the act of revisiting, Huang reconstructs moments from her past that blur the line between documentation and imagination. The seaside becomes a site for examining how memory functions, shaped by distance, repetition, and time. By translating personal recollections into visual form, she reflects on how individual memory connects to broader experiences of place, belonging, and cultural transition.

title: they had become beacons of light unto eachother
description:
I want this work, and its language, to speak for itself, so I’m keeping the following description plain and not weighed down by a detached theoretical frame. 
The work is best displayed on the linked webpage
This work stems, at its core, from two places:
.The concepts explored in my dissertation surrounding how myths, alchemy, and stories can help us create new realities from fiction.

.And secondly, from a beautiful moment I had with a pigeon.

The work is an ongoing exploration of how pigeons are seen in culture, compared to the intimate stories and moments people share with them. It pairs videos of pigeons being herded around parks—disrupting people’s pathways and forcing them to notice the pigeons—with a collection of stories exploring the deep connection between pigeons and those who live on the edges of society, and what this connection may mean for the collective unconscious.

profile: Jooyeong Moon explores extinction, bodily and ecological metamorphosis, and the shifting boundary between technology and life. Trained in animal science and completing an MA in Art & Ecology, she combines field research, participatory projects, poetic writing, and experimental moving-image to construct fictional narratives. Rooted in emotional and philosophical reflection, her works re-imagine humanity’s entanglement with the more-than-human world.
title: Voices of the Imagined Islands: EvanescentSusurrus,
material: video projection, sound, mirror, wood, light
description:
What is an island made of?
Paradoxically, it is the surrounding water that completes the island. What defines the island lies not within, but outside of it.

Thinking of the flowing waters that trace the island’s edges, I often imagine myself turning into water. In that stillness, the island feels like a delicate life gently held within me, like a fetus resting in the sea of myself.

Perhaps the island is not isolated but deeply entangled with the sea. When the island and the sea reflect, absorb, and dissolve into one another, the island becomes a space where opposites coexist: birth and death, solitude and connection, drifting and anchoring.

From this symbolic interplay, I imagined a fictional island: EvanescentSusurrus. The name combines “Evanescent” (fleeting) and “Susurrus” (a soft whisper). It is a quiet refuge for beings suspended between presence and disappearance.

Over a month, I visited Spanish islands and interviewed people I met by chance. Their voices, dreams, images, sounds, collected materials, and writing fragments gradually converged into one evolving story.

I asked islanders to share memories, secrets, and personal experiences. Some imagined the island as a living being, describing its scent, form, and voice. Others envisioned becoming nonhuman, wondering how they might perceive the world, relate to humans, and what they would long for if they never returned.

This project gathers physical and symbolic fragments from real islands. Like stars forming a constellation, these voices connect to create the imaginary island EvanescentSusurrus.

In the work, shaped by the image of water, visitors encounter these fragments and form their connections. If Narcissus once saw himself in the water, we now meet reflections of others, including nonhuman beings.

Islands are no longer fixed forms. Like drifting lands breathing with the sea, may we each become a quiet, free-floating fragment gently moving through the world.

profile:
I am an artist living and practicing in London. My work explores the oppression of women through the lenses of appearance-based discrimination and sexual violence. Drawing from my perspective as a Japanese woman raised in a patriarchal society, I create sculptures, installations, and paintings using materials such as metal, language, silicone, sound, and photography.

Born in Yamanashi and raised in Tokyo, I grew up surrounded by social expectations that dictated ‘how women should look and behave’. In a society like Japan, where harmony and conformity are highly valued, the subtle violence that occurs within communities often remains invisible, hidden beneath layers of silence. Phrases like ‘This is the right way for a Japanese woman to look’ are violently perpetuated through the media and extend to expectations around body size, hair length, and facial features. Sexual violence is widespread in workplaces, public spaces, and even among friends, yet most incidents remain unspoken, known only to the victims themselves.

Through my artistic practice, I confront these invisible forms of violence. By drawing attention to the normative frameworks we are made to believe as “normal,” I aim to expose their cruelty and destabilize the assumptions that govern our perception of the world. This process begins with personal history, experience, and memory. It seeks to connect these intimate origins with public contexts in which social issues take shape—navigating the tensions between the individual and society, and between the past and the present.
title: Sacrificial conformity
description:
This work seeks to expose the social structure in which women are expected to be “beautiful.”
The high heel, often celebrated as a symbol of glamour and elegance, is also an object that imposes strain and pain on the body.
With its thorn-studded form, this shoe magnifies that duality and materialises the “sacrifice demanded for beauty.”
It questions how we become bound by the gaze of others, and how, at times, we submit to pain in order to comply with beauty.

title: Cinderella
description:
A dream is a wish your heart makes.
Once upon a time, I believed that one day I could be Cinderella.
Many people taught me the magic words.
‘BE CUTE’
‘BE YOUNG’
‘BE HOMELY’
‘BE WEAK’
‘BE SELFLESS’
‘BE SEXY’
‘BE NICE’
As I came to realise, these words became a collar around which I tormented myself.
Once upon a time, I believed that one day I could be Cinderella.

profile: Kamonchanok Wongwiboonsat is a visual artist, interdisciplinary designer, and material researcher whose practice explores the emotional and cultural dimensions of material. Rooted in her family’s rice mill and guided by a commitment to sustainable innovation, she intertwines narrative, craft, and experimental material processes to blur the boundaries between art, design, and science. Her current research investigates the potential of rice husk silica as a ceramic glaze, developed through collaborations with local Thai rice farming communities dedicated to preserving indigenous rice varieties.
title: Regenesis
material: Rice husk silica,Rice husk biochar,Rice husk
description:
Saline soils in northeastern Thailand, particularly in Yasothon’s Thung Kula Ronghai fields, present significant challenges to rice cultivation. Drought, sandy textures, high salinity, and low organic matter limit nutrient and water retention, while alkaline conditions further reduce productivity, leaving farmers reliant on rainfall.

Communities draw resilience from environmental cycles and spiritual traditions, especially the annual Bun Bang Fai Rocket Festival, which invokes Naga, the mythical serpent of rain and fertility.

This project reinterprets the ceremonial rocket using indigenous rice husks from local mills and farming communities. Rich in silica and repurposed through craft processes, the husks support a circular, regenerative approach that benefits ecosystems, preserves traditional rice varieties, and honors cultural heritage.

Through pyrolysis, rice husks can also become biochar, enhancing soil structure, moisture retention, and long-term fertility. Returned to the fields after the symbolic rocket launch, rice husk silica and biochar act as regenerative agents, linking ritual, material, and ecology while restoring soil vitality.

school: Central Saint Martins College of Art
profile:
Canhe is a cross-media artist and researcher whose practice interrogates the entanglement of technology and human life. Working at the confluence of critical theory, media studies, and artistic experimentation, his work examines how contemporary technologies intervene in, reshape, and restructure everyday experience. He is particularly concerned with the shifting position of ordinary individuals within social structures under the dominance of grand technological narratives.

Canhe’s trajectory has recently moved from the position of a critical observer to that of an active constructor. He advances the speculative framework of temporary alliances between “ordinary humans” and “ordinary machines”—a counter-hegemonic imagination that challenges the monopolization of creativity and agency by technological elites. This concept is being developed textually and will be tested through practice, as Yang seeks to confront the intensifying dynamics of digital colonialism and technological hegemony in the globalized present.

His practice spans a wide range of media—from installation and sculpture to interactive systems—reflecting a refusal to be confined by disciplinary boundaries. Beyond his artistic production, Yang has provided digital art services for leading institutions including Adidas International, the National Museum of China, Alibaba, and Cosmo magazine. In 2022, he became a contracted digital artist with Output. Currently, he directs R&C Design Studio, an experimental design practice exploring how generative AI intersects with material culture to reimagine the mechanisms of cultural heritage reproduction.

Canhe is also active in pedagogy and knowledge exchange. He has taught as a visiting lecturer at the Central Academy of Fine Arts and the Beijing Institute of Fashion Technology, delivering courses on GenAI-enabled cultural heritage innovation and technologically driven art and design. He is now affiliated with the School of Creativity and Innovation at Xiamen University, where he supports the University for the Creative Arts (UCA) teaching team in courses on media art, spatial narratives, and design foundations.

In both practice and theory, Canhe’s work insists on making visible the infrastructures and ideologies embedded in contemporary technologies, while opening speculative pathways toward more egalitarian human–machine futures.
title: Mr
description:
Where is the Price explores the hidden material and ethical dimensions of artificial intelligence through the lens of Geological Echo Memory—a concept that views the Earth as an active archive of technological history.
Tracing the material supply chain of AI—from mineral extraction and chip fabrication to data centers and e-waste—the work exposes how every act of computation leaves geological residues.

Based on this research, I created a new image of AI: a cumbersome, non-interactive, materially grounded sculpture that embodies the physical burden of digital intelligence. This heavy, unresponsive body stands as irrefutable evidence that AI is not “in the cloud,” but deeply rooted in matter, labor, and planetary extraction.

Through sculpture, animation, and investigative mapping, the work transforms data extraction into an act of remembrance. It listens to the echoes of resources, myths, and generations—inviting viewers to confront technology not as immaterial progress, but as a living, earthly memory.

profile:
Yunzhi / Melissa Li is a Chengdu-born, London-based computational artist whose practice spans interactive installations, web-based experiments and immersive 3D environments. She examines how images, code, and audience interaction shape our sense of identity, memory and place. Her works have been exhibited at the Victoria and Albert Museum, the Photographers’ Gallery, Hypha Studios, Copeland Gallery, and Greatorex Street Gallery, among others.

At the heart of Li’s work is the translation of the intangible experiences, making the unseen visible. She gathers data, whether that is from public image archives, 3D scans of everyday objects and recordings of personal stories, and then layers them into physical and digital spaces. Chairs, tables and screens become shifting canvases where virtual textures appear to merge with the material world. This blending of online and organic systems invites viewers to consider how their personal experiences, histories and digital traces intertwine.

Beyond gallery walls, Li co-leads art collective Cranberry Lemonade workshops in HTML, CSS and JavaScript, inviting participants to demystify web creation and tell their own digital stories.

Looking forward, she plans to further develop this collaborative model by integrating sensor networks and community-sourced data, creating site-responsive installations that blend personal histories into immersive experiences.
title: Home is a dwelling path
material: Interactive digital game, bunk-bed structure, ceramic bowl
description: The installation merges an explorative 3D environment with a physical installation that mirrors its digital textures. Visitors navigate through an ambient, exploratory digital space with surreal home-like landscapes built from recorded memories, personal, and found materials. Drawing from lived experiences of displacement and cultural hybridity, it invites reflection on how homes are mentally constructed and emotionally distorted.

profile:
My practice is rooted in a profound connection to the natural world, where I explore the entangled relationships between landscape, memory, and emotion. Currently focusing on transformed geographies of the fens, I investigate how land altered by human intervention becomes a site for both ecological tension and personal reflection. These shifting geographies operate as emotional cartographies—mapping grief, joy, loss, and resilience.

Through painting, I examine how systems of power and patriarchy have shaped both environment and identity. Reclaimed and eroded terrains offer metaphors for challenging structures of control, while also inviting more fluid, reciprocal ways of relating to place. My work proposes that ancient knowledge lingers in the land—in silty residues, ghost rivers, and unseen traces—waiting to be listened to rather than extracted.

Walking, writing, and sketching on-site inform a studio process driven by material curiosity. I work across media, layering, scraping back, and rebuilding, allowing the paintings to unfold intuitively. Embracing ambiguity and material agency, I seek to create contemplative spaces that resist resolution and invite attunement.
My research draws on object-oriented ontology, ecological theory, and feminist philosophy, with influences including Jane Bennett, Tim Morton, and Gilles Deleuze. I explore the Anthropocene not just as an environmental condition but as a psychological one, asking what becomes possible when we relinquish the need to dominate.

Bio:
I returned full-time to my practice in 2022 after a career in business. I hold a Postgraduate Diploma in Fine Art from the Royal College of Art (2024) and an MA in Fine Art from Falmouth University (2025), both awarded with distinction. Recently completing an MA in Painting at RCA, I was shortlisted for the 2025 Valerie Beston Award. I have exhibited in London and Cambridge, including a 2024 solo show at Safehouse 2, and my work is held in private collections.
title: The Passage of Time I & II
description:
This diptych, The Passage of Time explores a semi-abstract landscape rendered in a restrained, monochromatic palette. The work draws on the language of gesture—scratches, brushstrokes, and scored marks—made through layers of oil paint and cold wax on linen. These surfaces record both presence and absence, the visible and the obscured, much like the land itself.

The composition evokes a terrain shaped by time and touch, altered by the persistent hand of human intervention. What once may have been open, fluid, and organic is now demarcated, controlled, or erased. Yet the painting resists moral judgement. Instead, it invites the viewer into a slowed, attentive mode of looking—one that mirrors the patience required in both landscape observation and the painterly process.

Here, the truth is not documentary but felt. It emerges through surface tension, through the act of making and unmaking, of concealing and revealing. The duality of the diptych reflects transformation: one panel perhaps more intact, the other more fragmented—suggesting a before and after, or a continual oscillation between states. This is a meditation on how land remembers, how marks linger, and how looking itself can be a radical, reparative act.

school: School of Jewellery， Birmingham City University
major: Master of Art Jewellery and Related Products
profile:
Zhixin Mai is a contemporary jeweller working with the combination of natural wood and silver. Her practice focuses on gender fluidity, the metaphor of trees and transformation, aiming to explore more possibilities of diverse identities rooted in nature. 

Her works have been presented at the MA Graduate Exhibition at the School of Jewellery, Birmingham City University, as well as in Saturn Garden, London (September 2025). Also they will be presented on Echoes in Transition,London in November 2025. She has recently completed her MA in Jewellery Design at Birmingham City University. 

Her practice is informed by cross-disciplinary research in ecology and queer studies, bringing together material experimentation and conceptual exploration. 

She is currently based in China.
title: Emergent Self
description: This work is based on the idea that both humans and trees originated from nature. Emergent Self symbolises the transformation and breakthrough of gender fluidity. The gender symbols of silver form extends and intertwines with the wood structure, representing the emergence of identity that grows beyond binary limitations. Through the contrast between natural wood and metal, this piece explores how individuality unfolds when social constraints have been broke through. The making process involved wax carving, casting and combining both materials by riveting and welding, allowing each to influence the other's surface and form. It captures the process of awakening — Break free from the shackles and define yourself.

title: Infinite Fluidity
description: Infinite Fluidity defines gender fluidity as an ongoing, non-linear process of identity formation. Drawing from the shared natural origin between humans and trees, the work illustrates the possibilities of exploring multiple selves. The naturally shed bark symbolises each unique individual, while the silver’s sharp outer contour and soft inner outline represent the tension between social constraints and the body’s inner fluidity. Surrounding the wooden form, silver creates a continuous dialogue between confinement and transformation. The five individual units can be freely assembled through clasp structures, functioning as brooches or necklaces depending on their arrangement. This combination of formal expression and multifunctional design highlights the infinite possibilities of self-definition and identity transformation.

profile: Kamonchanok Wongwiboonsat is a visual artist, interdisciplinary designer, and material researcher whose practice explores the emotional and cultural dimensions of material. Rooted in her family’s rice mill and guided by a commitment to sustainable innovation, she intertwines narrative, craft, and experimental material processes to blur the boundaries between art, design, and science. Her current research investigates the potential of rice husk silica as a ceramic glaze, developed through collaborations with local Thai rice farming communities dedicated to preserving indigenous rice varieties.
title: Mae Phosop
description:
This project reimagines a sacred totem by blending modern technology with traditional agricultural rituals that have gradually faded since the Green Revolution. As belief in spiritual nature forces diminishes and reliance on chemicals grows, the project seeks to rekindle a sense of reverence toward nature.

In Thailand, Mae Phosop, the revered goddess of rice, is believed to protect the fields and bring prosperity to farmers. By intertwining this cultural symbol with innovation, the project honors and preserves the deep connection between spirituality and agriculture, encouraging farmers to reconnect with their land through data collection and deeper understanding of their fields, sustaining Mae Phosop’s blessings through care and devotion.

To pay homage to Mae Phosop, symbolic objects such as a mirror, scissors, and comb represent her beauty and divine presence. The hexagonal mirror reflects the belief that the number six offers protection against insects and pests, while a fragrant powder embodies the goddess’s elegance, much like the adornments of a woman preparing for a sacred ritual.

profile: I am Xinyi Mao, an Industrial designer from a multi-ethnic region in Southwest China. My work explores themes of identity, minority empowerment, cultural memory, and emotional resonance. Growing up in an ethnic minority region, I have become deeply aware of the tensions between tradition and modernity, visibility and erasure. Through my practice, I strive to create sensitive, story-driven experiences that bridge cultures and foster dialogue. I am particularly interested in how design can serve as both a reflective and empowering tool for underrepresented communities, especially those whose stories have long been marginalised, overlooked, or forgotten.
title: Threads of Song, Echoes of Weave
description:
Threads of Song, Echoes of Weave is an interactive installation inspired by the Dong ethnic group’s iconic drum tower architecture. It emerges from a personal exploration of cultural identity, rooted in the lived experience of growing up in a multi-ethnic region in Southwest China. The installation seeks to evoke empathy by drawing audiences into a subtle emotional space shaped by nostalgia, homesickness, and a quiet sense of belonging. These emotional tones become a means for engaging with the deeper significance of intangible cultural heritage.

The drum tower’s layered structure is clad in Dong cloth, a stiff, natural indigo-dyed textile with a distinctive sheen, and adorned with handwoven ribbons crafted by local Dong women. Audiences interact with it by tapping a small Dong drum, triggering soundscapes of the Dong Grand Song, while hidden scrolls containing cultural stories can be manually drawn from each level. By encouraging sensory engagement with overlooked traditions, the project aims to redirect attention to ethnical minority communities whose voices and cultures are often underrepresented.

profile:
I am a London-based jewellery designer whose work is deeply inspired by the natural world. A graduate of the Glasgow School of Art, where I studied Jewellery Design and Silversmithing, I strive to capture the essence of landscapes and transform them into wearable forms. My practice explores the intersection between high-end and fashion jewellery, seeking to push the boundaries of how jewellery can be experienced and worn.

https://www.torquilgordon.com
title: Lands of Bent Grass
description:
‘Lands of Bent Grass’ takes inspiration from the island landscapes of the Outer Hebrides, aiming to capture their raw and distinctive character through jewellery. The collection reflects the balance between fragility and strength found in these remote environments, from the movement of windswept grasses to the rugged coastline and dramatic weather.
My creative process starts with being out in the landscape, observing and recording through photography, sketching, and film. In the workshop, these observations are developed into designs, exploring how texture, form, and movement can be expressed in metal. I combine traditional goldsmithing techniques with modern technologies such as 3D printing, merging the old with new to create pieces that honour tradition while embracing innovation.

profile:
Yudan is a London-based multidisciplinary artist whose practice explores the affective dimensions of embodiment, intimacy, and
maternal experience. Working across illustration, soft sculpture, and 3D digital media, she engages with materials that are pliable,
tactile, and often unstable—mirroring the fluid, often contradictory nature of caregiving and emotional labor.Her work resists binary
separations between art and life, instead positioning motherhood as both method and epistemology. Through gestures of folding,
layering, and suspension, Yudan constructs spaces of quiet intensity—where muted emotions, fragmented selfhood, and relational
tensions can be felt rather than resolved. In doing so, she proposes softness as both aesthetic and critical strategy.
title: Love to fish
categories: Love and Relationship Dynamics,Gender,Symbolism and Biblical Imagery
description:
What is true love and how to love a person? Jewish philosopher Abraham Twerski argued that the word “love” had lost its original meaning and was slowly being misunderstood. He told a very interesting story. Kotzk came across a young man who was eating fish, and he went over to him and asked, “why are you eating this fish?” The young man answered without thinking, “because I love fish！”Kotzk followed: “You love this fish, so you pull it out of the water, kill it and cook it. Come on, please don’t tell me you love this fish, it is yourself that you love because this fish tastes delicious.”
In my own experience of love, I am no different from the fish. The so-called “love” in a relationship is like the “love for fish”, which is based on certain qualities that he likes. But this love is also based on social rules that he should contribute more to the other as a partner. However, I myself feel like an imprisoned individual. My partner’s so-called “good for you” and “love you” are actually just to satisfy himself, expect you to change for him and become what he wants, which is actually a manifestation of his love for himself.
“People who like flowers will pick them to appreciate, and those who love flowers will water them silently.” There is a lot of love in the world, but most of it is “love for fish”.
In the project, I put my personal feelings and emotions into the picture as my reflection on the relationship between partners.
Most of the images in the picture take apples as inspirations. In the Bible story, apple is a forbidden fruit, representing pleasure and enjoyment, especially sexual pleasure. It has such a symbolic meaning, probably because its core is like the shape of female vulva. In Latin, apple is spelled the same way as “wrong”, both of which are “Malum”, so apple is a pun - Eve did wrong by eating the apple. The apple has always been a sort of conflicted symbol of love and lust.

profile: Finnish-Peruvian artist working both with ceramics and music. Drawing inspiration from the richness of Peruvian culture and the elegance and minimalism of Nordic design. His practice explores the contrast between these two worlds, striving to elevate them by harnessing each of their strengths. Visually informed by digital aesthetics such as 2000s internet culture, video games and electronic music. High quality craftsmanship and a respect for who's come before him sit at the core of Johan's hybrid identity as an artist.
title: HEAD OF AI APAEC
description:
Interpretation of the godly deity Ai Apaec. Prominently depicted in archaeological vessel findings from Peru dating to the Moche period between 100-700 A.D.

Represented as a man with the powers of the feline, the bird and the snake. On his quest to retrieve the sun and subsequently restore order in the natural world, he was decapitated and fell into the depths of the underworld.

A modern take on a universal tale of the hero. Fully finished in a dark, metallic sheen over a hand built red stoneware body.

profile:
Shenlu’s artistic practice centers on textiles, extending into installation, moving image, and sensory interaction to explore the nonlinear relationships between body, emotion, and energy. In a time when tactile experience is increasingly blurred and the visualization of emotion is over-commodified, she transforms seemingly gentle acts of repetition—knitting, weaving, embroidery, and pattern-making—into mechanisms that respond to what she calls a “crisis of perception.”

She articulates a visual language of “ornamental energy shells”: protective yet intimate structures built from sequins, colors, and yarns. These patterned surfaces become sites of emotional projection, reflecting anxiety, memory, and the fragile bond between humans and nature. Through her work, the body is recalled as a sensory interface, while textiles emerge as tactile spiritual devices—tools for reconnection and resonance in an era of sensory decline.

In Shenlu’s practice, softness is not surrender, and ornamentation is never superficial. Fabric becomes a medium for micro but enduring disturbances of perception, nurturing the regeneration of emotional landscapes.
title: SiO2.F4hz.T3s Pluse Coil
categories: Textile Sculpture and Material Experimentation,Artificial Lifeforms,Energy and Spirituality
description:
This textile-based sculpture operates as a mimetic organism, oscillating between material experiment and speculative lifeform. Constructed from silicone and handwoven textile structures, the work evokes the tension between artificial fabrication and organic emergence.

The translucent silicone joints fuse with fiber networks, forming skeletal geometries that recall both crystalline growth and biological membranes. Its luminous surfaces suggest a body in flux—part mineral, part organism— inhabiting a threshold state between technological artifact and imagined species. By merging silicone’s pliable resilience with the fragile tactility of textile, the piece generates an “energetic anatomy”: a speculative coil where softness becomes structural and ornamentation encodes vitality. The work proposes textile not only as surface or pattern, but as a system capable of simulating metabolic flow, magnetic resonance, and the poetics of nonhuman embodiment.

It is an interactive textile installation situated at the intersection of science and spirituality. The series reconsiders how can document, fragment, and recompose the perceptual dialogue between energy and the body.

profile: Rooted in the intersection of painting, composite materials, and identity politics, Yifan's works explore the self expression of individuals constantly flowing and reconstructing in a multicultural context. With a professional training background in illustration, his creations have expanded deeply into the field of integrated material installations, integrating painting foundations, ready-made objects, and diverse media. Yifan's practice is visually experimental and materialistic, while conceptually dedicated to deconstructing a single cultural narrative. Its core themes revolve around the hybridity of personal identity, the translation of cultural symbols, and more inclusive expression possibilities. By integrating personal memories, cultural symbols, and social metaphors into a material dialogue, Yifan challenges inherent identity boundaries and constructs a visual field that explores cultural belonging and individual uniqueness. His works are not only reflections on personal experiences, but also aim to provide an open, fluid, and material critical new perspective for understanding identity under the interweaving of diverse cultures.
title: Clover
categories: Cross-Cultural Identity and Coexistence,Spiritual Symbolism and Visual Anthropology,Religion
description:
Clover is a visual project developed by Zorg based on long-term field research in an East London neighborhood. It explores how cultural totems, spiritual narratives, and everyday ornamentationintersect and regenerate within a space of multi-ethnic cohabitation.

Zorg conducted in-depth research in a diverse community where people of Asian, Arab, African, and European backgrounds live side by side, each with their own religious and cultural traditions. Some Asian residents practiceBuddhism; individuals of African heritage share stories connected to ancient Egyptian mythology; while many white residents follow Christian or Catholic faiths. The layering of beliefs and ethnicities forms a richly complex cultural landscape within the neighborhood.
Throughout his research, Zorg built relationships with local residents, listening closely to their stories and mythologies. He restructured these cross-cultural and spiritual narrativesinto a new visual form, inspiredby a symbolic window found within the community. The resulting work becomes not only a visual reconstruction of belief systems, but also a narrative space where multiple cultural voices are woven together and reimagined.

As residents arrived from different parts of the world, they brought with them their own visual symbols, totems, and decorative languages. Over time, these elements have been continually reassembled, hybridized, and reinterpreted within the shared spaceresulting in a distinct visual language specific to the community itself. This symbolic system is not only present in the stories residents tell, but also embedded in the visual fabric of the neighborhood: in shopfronts, signage, wall decorations, and handmade crafts. it forms a mixed image archive,encompassing Buddhist totems.Egyptian hieroglyphs, lslamic geometric patterns,and Christian iconography-a living testament to cross-cultural coexistence and visual negotiation.

profile: Jingjing Xu's artistic practice consistently engages with the question of how women confront adversity. Employing the metaphor of the boulder from the Greek myth of Sisyphus, she reflects the cyclical struggles women face in breaking free from societal discipline, while further exploring how women reconstruct their identities and redefine notions of belonging and freedom amidst the tensions between tradition and modernity, society and the individual, and fiction and reality. Her methodology emphasizes dialogue and recognition: through interactions with the self, nature, and society, the artist achieves individual liberation and subjective reconfiguration. This practice not only responds to forces of domination and normalization but also embodies a relational politics grounded in interdependence and mutual recognition, proposing art as a critical intervention for reflecting upon and restructuring gendered social frameworks.
title: Sisyphus
categories: Existentialism and Absurdism,Rebellion and Human Resilience,Myth Reinterpretation
description:
Set within the philosophical framework of Camus’ absurdism, the myth of Sisyphus is reimagined here as a contemporary parable of “the absurd” and “rebellion.” The film turns its gaze toward this eternal cycle: the boulder rolls down, only to be pushed up again—transforming what appears to be a futile, repetitive action into a persistent inquiry into the meaning of existence.

Within this endless repetition, Sisyphus responds to the void through his very act, imbuing the absurd with meaning. The work is not merely a reenactment of myth, but seeks to mirror the existential predicament of the modern individual: amid the day-to-day labor and structural impasses, each of us pushes our own boulder. Here, “meaning” no longer resides in a distant endpoint, but is instead rooted in the continual struggle against the void—the ongoing, upward process itself.

profile: Songer Yang is a visual artist working across painting, graphic design, and narrative forms. Rooted in personal memory, her practice explores themes of family, femininity, and the emotional weight of domestic rituals. She often uses repetitive hand labor to reflect on healing, grief, and the quiet persistence of love. Born in Shaoxing, Zhejiang, China, she holds a BFA in Illustration from the School of Visual Arts and an MFA in 2D Design from Cranbrook Academy of Art.
title: Pray
description: Pray is a silent meditation on grief, memory, and the invisible labor of care. The very things that once sheltered us can also bring harm, leaving deep and heavy scabs on both body and spirit. It is not a religious prayer, but a personal ritual of endurance and remembrance—a quiet, sincere reaching toward faith. I often feel there is an unseen force around me, appearing just as I am about to collapse or lose hope, gently guiding me forward. In those moments, I encounter people and experiences filled with a kind of quiet spirituality, as if everything had been arranged by something greater than myself.

profile: Songer Yang is a visual artist working across painting, graphic design, and narrative forms. Rooted in personal memory, her practice explores themes of family, femininity, and the emotional weight of domestic rituals. She often uses repetitive hand labor to reflect on healing, grief, and the quiet persistence of love. Born in Shaoxing, Zhejiang, China, she holds a BFA in Illustration from the School of Visual Arts and an MFA in 2D Design from Cranbrook Academy of Art.
title: Curtain
description: Curtain draws from a quiet childhood memory: waking earlier than my parents and staring at the patterned curtain beside our bed. My gaze would follow the lines of the plaid, weaving in and out of its rhythm. Sometimes it made me dizzy. Sometimes it made me feel safe.

profile: Songer Yang is a visual artist working across painting, graphic design, and narrative forms. Rooted in personal memory, her practice explores themes of family, femininity, and the emotional weight of domestic rituals. She often uses repetitive hand labor to reflect on healing, grief, and the quiet persistence of love. Born in Shaoxing, Zhejiang, China, she holds a BFA in Illustration from the School of Visual Arts and an MFA in 2D Design from Cranbrook Academy of Art.
title: Good Kid
description: Inspired by childhood memories of earning star stickers in kindergarten. I loved coming home each day and peeling the red star stickers from my forehead, arranging them in rows on the wall like trophies on display. But I could never make them perfectly straight, and eventually, I gave up.

profile: Songer Yang is a visual artist working across painting, graphic design, and narrative forms. Rooted in personal memory, her practice explores themes of family, femininity, and the emotional weight of domestic rituals. She often uses repetitive hand labor to reflect on healing, grief, and the quiet persistence of love. Born in Shaoxing, Zhejiang, China, she holds a BFA in Illustration from the School of Visual Arts and an MFA in 2D Design from Cranbrook Academy of Art.
title: Spoon
description:
Spoon began with a spoon I lost about 10 years—the one I always used to eat my grandmother’s steamed egg. It held a private bond with my family, a silent thread tying together nourishment, love, intimacy, and even the quiet privileges and favoritism that only existed around our dining table. When it disappeared, it felt like a piece of my history had been cut out, a gap that no other object could fill. Maybe I’m just a stubborn person.
So I tried to bring it back. My grandpa taught me how to hammer copper, using scraps from an old rice cooker and other broken appliances we had at home. For a whole month, I made one spoon a day, working only from memory, as if only this way could call it back. But as the days went on and the number of spoons grew higher, doubt crept in: were these still my spoon? At some point, I could no longer picture its exact look—the memory faded into a blur, just an abstract kind of energy I couldn’t hold or rebuild. My obsession kept trying to grab what was already gone, and yet, stubbornly, I kept on trying to grab it anyway.

profile:
I focus on the folklore and cultural gaps where vague, unnamed emotions and symbols reside. These marginalized narratives often carry deep layers of collective memory and personal experience. Though unstable and fragmented, they possess a kind of truth and power. Through surrealist storytelling, I seek to reawaken these hidden cultural fragments and give them a renewed visual context.

In my practice, unease is a guiding emotion. It is not meant to create fear, but to awaken the viewer’s sensitivity and prompt reflection on the structures, symbols, and subconscious forces behind the image. I am drawn to subtle details and symbolic constructions, allowing the image itself to become a poetic and open experience.
title: Guhuo Birds
description: This work is inspired by the Chinese folklore of the Gu Huo Niao—a spirit said to be born from mothers who died in childbirth, wandering the night to steal other people’s children. I intertwine this ancient legend with the modern reality of child trafficking, reimagining it through a surrealist lens. In this narrative, the boundaries between reality and myth blur, giving new meaning to a traditional tale. Through distorted visual storytelling, the piece explores themes of motherhood, loss, and longing, shedding light on the hidden and often overlooked darkness within modern society.

profile:
Currently caught between London & Paris, Nora Beckman is in a state of flux. Pushing out from childhood along the Oregon coast, to college in Massachusetts, into working in art and fashion in New York City, then a decade in LA founding and running an experimental retail space and an artist-centered Hiking Club. Post-pandemic led her to an MA in London at Central Saint Martins. Currently Nora runs events, builds collaborations, reads incessantly, critiques structures, and writes.

Mina Beckman is a multi-disciplinary maker, jeweller, poet, space organiser, and energy worker. Drawing inspiration from ancient sacred sites like Delphi, Stonehenge, and the Well of Santa Christina, she is interested in joining spiritual, metaphysical, and physical worlds. Mina completed an MA at the Royal College of Art in 2024 in jewellery and metal, looking at transmuting overlooked spaces, encouraging motion in stagnation with attention and awareness. She is the sister of Nora Beckman.

Maks Hara is a lawyer, painter, sculptor, seeker, and researcher of myth, symbolism, mysticism and theology, currently pursuing a postgraduate degree in competition economics, all stemming from his interest in exploring the many worlds that we inhabit, and entering into conversation with their mysteries and paradoxes. Originally from the small town of Szczytna, nestled in the mountains and forests of southwestern Poland, he has lived primarily in London for the last two decades.
title: Seeking Delphi
categories: Sound and Print,Art and Archaeology,Figurative Spiritual Anthropology
description:
“We arrive winding through mountains with gasps of delight. Then suddenly it’s Delphi, the Castalian Spring emerging from the deep ravine between the Phaedriades, fenced and locked away…”

Our trifecta Flesh, Bones, and Magic journeyed to the archaeological site of Delphi to engage and listen.

The resulting project, Seeking Delphi is a sound piece combining sonic elements recorded on-site in the 2,700 year-old archaeological site and ruins with voiced texts written on location, palimpsesting Classical religious traditions with contemporary somatic and cognitive reflections. 

Delphi was unique as an ancient spiritual site in that the prophetic oracles were delivered orally by the Pythia priestesses, centering sound as an important method of transmission. 

The sound piece is accompanied by a booklet of experimental and expository prose and images refracting the experience of engaging physically with Delphi, as well as utilizing extensive research at the British Library into its historical significance.

The gift is us
And this is enough
Us inhabiting us
Know thyself
Inhabit thyself
Be thyself
Love thyself

Flesh, Bones, and Magic is a collective that excavates currents of ancient and surviving religious and spiritual behavior and interaction through site visits to archaeologically relevant locales. The trio has a deep interest in the energetics of ritual, in esoteric threads that weave into contemporary life, as well as in the context of ancient spiritual traditions' absorptive drift into modern knowledge bases and religions.

profile:
Ekaterina Adelskaya is a London-based artist of Russian and Ukrainian heritage. Working across sculpture, installation and video, she explores the intersections between memory, materiality, and transformative processes. 
Fire, heat, and cooking methods are her primary alchemical techniques. In her current research she examines potatoes as perishable roots that mutate and resist stasis. Potatoes recall home, home becomes laboratory, metal flexes strength.
title: Lineage
material: Wax and bronze cast potatoes,repurposed kitchen chopping board,painted metal brackets, screws
description:
Cast in wax and bronze, these potatoes speak of roots - both botanical and ancestral. Potatoes divide and regenerate, carrying their own lineage, just as I seek to understand mine. Fragile wax makes the bronze possible: a metaphor for memory - fragmented and fleeting, yet leaving behind enduring traces that solidify into heritage.

The potatoes bear thin cuts and grater marks, recalling both the act of cooking and the texture of ‘deruni’ - potato pancakes cherished by the women in my family. 

Placed on my reused kitchen chopping board, transformed into a shelf and altar, the work honours the domestic labour of my mother and grandmother, for whom the kitchen, where potatoes were prepared and shared, was the heart of the home. The humble root becomes a symbol of memory, transformation, and generational continuity.

title: Medusa Octopus from Nuclear Waste Mutant Creatures
description:
"Nuclear Waste: Mutant Creatures," investigates humanity's fears of the unknown and the repercussions of our actions on ecosystems through innovative fabric-making methods. The unpredictable effects of nuclear radiation, which transcend species boundaries, are explored in this collection. While current visible impacts are primarily
observed in oceanic mutations, the potential for these effects to extend to humans and animals poses a future fraught with unforeseen consequences. This dystopian collection serves as a cautionary tale about the perils of nuclear radiation and the anxieties
surrounding mutant creatures. The “Medusa Octopus” represents the mutation in-between land animals and sea animals, which represents how the radiation can transform non-toxic organism into poisonous animals.

profile: Di Cao is a multidisciplinary artist based in London whose work combines metaphorical narrative with practical craft in the context of digital surrealism and contemporary design. Can’s work orbits around eternal dualities between nature and artifice, absence and solidity, self and cosmos. His sculptures and digital arts represent a Heraclitean flow, where everything is always becoming.
title: Fragile
description: Fragile is a moving-image work that reimagines systems of natural classification by framing insects within ornate, almost sacred compositions. The piece questions how beauty, fragility, and scientific order intersect, exposing the tension between humanity’s desire to preserve and the inevitable transience of life. Through animated illustration, insects—often overlooked or reduced to specimens—are recast as subjects of reverence and vulnerability. Their delicate forms, suspended in shifting frames, reveal both the authority and the limitations of taxonomy: to hold life still is to risk confining it, yet in doing so, its fleeting nature becomes more sharply visible. Blending digital media with visual ornament, Fragile transforms the act of observation into a meditation on care, mortality, and the fragile balance between control and release. By collapsing boundaries between classification and contemplation, the work seeks to evoke a poetic language of becoming—where the natural world resists containment yet continues to shape how we understand beauty, value, and transformation.

profile: Based in London, Sindi Como is a visual artist and photographer whose work blends portraiture and landscape photography with a strong focus on storytelling. A graduate of the London College of Communication, Sindi creates photo books and visual projects that explore emotion, narrative, and place. Their practice investigates the connection between nature and the human body, examining how they mirror, influence, and coexist with one another. With experience in travel photography and collaborative projects, Sindi’s work spans digital and print formats, offering fresh perspectives and a deep sense of connection.
title: Disfigured
description:
Disfigured is a deeply personal project that explores my experience of growing up with an emotionally abusive father and the lasting impact it has had on me. The project began when I chose to remove him from my life, channelling anger and the need for healing into my artistic process. Through this work, I aim to give form to the complex emotions that shaped my journey into adulthood.

The images were taken in natural settings to express my emotional connection to nature and to reflect on the historical relationship between women and the landscape. Once used by male artists to diminish women, this relationship has been reclaimed by contemporary female artists as a symbol of strength and liberation. For me, nature represents freedom from the domestic environment in which I was raised. If exhibited, I envision the work displayed in a domesticated space reminiscent of my home, creating a dialogue between the open, liberating quality of the natural world and the confined, toxic spaces of my past.

Ultimately, Disfigured marks a process of transformation and release. By reworking childhood photographs and removing my father’s presence, I confront the distortion and loss of self that defined my upbringing. The title reflects both this emotional disfigurement and the visual outcome of my process, which employs burning and abstraction to express inner turmoil and the reclamation of identity.

title: YELLOW MONOCHROMES
description:
“Things are abstract in the non-visible, the transcendental goal of every path or journey. Individuals and phenomena dissolve through their own immediate existence.”
(Massimo Cacciari)*1

The monochromatic surfaces are built up through intense layering and sanding back of oil paint over time to create a sense of disintegration, irregularity, dissoloution and imperfection. These layers relate to the way in which layers are built up and worn down through the natural processes of time. This process also helps to create a sense of “Yugen” an Asian concept which means inexpressible depth or invisible beauty. This idea explores fleeting moments of awareness and sudden realisations of the transient nature of life which happen in the experience of “true reality”.                                              

This work arises from the study of Japanese aesthetic philosophy combined with research into of the place of spirituality in contemporary postmodern society and its influence on monochromatic painting.

1. “Monochromes, From Malevich to the present.”

Rose, Barbara

Page 174

University of California Press

profile:
Maya Hirasawa（平澤）Brauer (b. 1997) of HRSW Studios is a visual artist working across painting, sculpture, installation, and new media. Born in Tokyo amidst bright neon lights and character-filled streets, Hirasawa’s work lies between the cute and the unsettling, weaving personal and collective mythologies into contemporary visual language. Their practice reinterprets inherited iconographies and emotional rituals through the lens of queer and diasporic experience, exploring how identity and memory are continually reshaped across cultures.

Through fluid, often deformed humanoid figures that fight, play, and merge within structured environments, Hirasawa examines the body as both subject and site — a vessel for transformation and resistance. These beings become living archives of human connection, embodying tensions between tenderness and fragmentation, self and other. In reimagining traditional symbols of spirituality and emotional expression, Hirasawa positions their work within a lineage of artists who act as both guardians and reconstructors of culture, breathing new life into the forms and energies that traverse generations and geographies.
title: Equal Pulse
description: This painting depicts a Buddha-like form with overlapping faces, embodying a moment of energetic resonance between two beings. The layered faces echo the multiplicity within self and other, a visual mantra that recalls devotional icons and ritual imagery while reimagining them through a contemporary lens. In this work, the sacred is not distant or historical, but something that emerges in human connection, where presence itself becomes a form of meditation. By blending spiritual symbolism with personal experience, Equal Pulse reactivates the contemplative stillness of traditional imagery into a living, shared pulse.

school: School of the Museum of Fine Arts
profile: Adina Andrus makes work that confronts questions of memory, belonging, and visual culture across time and space. Andrus is a recipient of the Queens Council for the Arts New Work Grant and the NY State Arts Alive Artist Grant and has exhibited work in the United States and Romania,  including at the Spring/Break Art Show (New York, NY), CollarWorks (Troy, NY), LABSpace Gallery (Hillsdale, NY), the Romanian Cultural Institute (New York, NY), and Make a Point Gallery (Bucharest, Romania). She studied art at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts and the Art Students’ League. Andrus lives and works in the New York area.
title: Some Things to Remember
description:
"Some Things to Remember" presents sculptural forms made of ceramic blended with bioplastic and gold. The pieces take on script-like qualities—organic shapes and marks that flow and cluster into installations resembling sentences or visual patterns. Gold accents catch light against textured ceramic, while the paintings echo similar motifs on flat surfaces. Some pieces stand alone while others gather into larger groups, establishing their own visual grammar that shifts with different angles and lighting.
The works function as keepsakes, preserving memories of places lived and experienced. Each piece acts as a visual record of specific moments and sensory details. By translating these memories—particularly those connected to food and daily rituals—into tangible forms, the artist explores how we preserve our connections to the places we've inhabited. The work invites viewers to reflect on the flavors, objects, and sensations that anchor their own sense of home across time and distance.

profile: Iris Kienzl (*2002, AT) is a media artist based in Vienna, currently studying Digital Arts at the University of Applied Arts. Her work includes 3D scans, animations, and, increasingly, the artistic exploration of abandoned spaces. Through her practice, she reflects on memory, decay, and digital preservation. Her video works, often marked by a subtly unsettling, surreal atmosphere, transform found material into immersive digital worlds.
title: Abandoned Inventory Series
description:
This series documents objects left behind in abandoned houses, transforming them into digital testimonies of everyday life, memory, and absence. Each inventory item is photographed and presented against a defocused 3D scan of its original interior, causing the objects to appear suspended in a neutral archival space. Many items—such as pharmaceuticals, magazines, or food—carry dates (e.g., expiration or publication dates) that function as time stamps of absence.

The series explores the question: what remains when routines are interrupted and daily life disappears? The documented objects are at once intimate and ordinary, bearing traces of personal and domestic memory that now appear as shadows of history. Each inventory reflects different aspects of domestic life.

The works are currently available as NFTs on objkt.com in the form of short videos.

profile: Amy Hsu Tzu Chen is a London-based Taiwanese textile artist who specialises in handcrafting vessels using techniques passed down by female artisans—such as basketry, embroidery, patching, and felting—which she reclaims as powerful forms of resistance and storytelling. Her practice intentionally positions these often undervalued female-related crafts as catalysts for social and cultural change. Through an intuitive process that honours instinct and emotion, Chen creates abstract, metaphorical forms, offering a poetic lens into the collective female psyche—its traumas, dreams, and inner landscapes. She is currently developing interactive haptic and sonic experiences that gently subvert gender norms and the role of female domestic crafts, inviting audiences into sensorial rituals that foster dialogue and empower human connections.
title: Gossip - Godsibb (her trusted friend)
description:
Gossip – Godsibb (her trusted friend) is a coiled vessel inspired by the historical context of the word gossip. Before negative and misogynistic connotations were imposed upon it, gossip—from the Old English Godsibb, originally referring to a godparent—described companions during childbirth, trusted confidants, and close female friends. It conveyed strong emotional bonds and social ties among women in premodern English society.

The making of this vessel seeks to create an organic form representing the nourishment and protection of a woman's “gossip circle,” reclaiming its original meanings and subverting the degradation of female voices and gatherings enforced by patriarchy.

By coiling wire with wool yarn, the malleable wire encapsulates the flexibility and resilience of feminine strength, while the wool yarn signifies the collective warmth of countless caring hands.

The process was both intuitive and intentional, shaping a symbolic structure resembling a group of women holding a well together, from which a cosmic egg is born. It began with forming four inner circular structures representing female circles, then building the well beneath, followed by an outer layer symbolising radiant light and protection, and finally, the cosmic egg inside the well. The unplanned yet natural progression of its formation is, in itself, a silent prayer of re-remembering.
