profile: Jenna Handley is a textile designer and material researcher whose practice sits at the intersection of traditional craft and innovative biomaterials. She explores how historical methods and ideas can be used as models for regenerative solutions with the aim of supporting both the heritage and future of textiles. Her current work encompasses seaweed based biomaterials and dyes, textile waste, and natural fibres.
title: SEAFOLK
description:
Seafolk reimagines Cornish seaweed as a sustainable natural dye and biomaterial. Rooted in place, craft, and community, the project partners with local knitters to revive regional resources and traditionally sustainable heritage techniques.

Seafolk responsibly harvests kelp to create fine fibres which can be spun into yarn. Dulse, a red macroalgae, is foraged for its soft pink pigment which is transformed into a dye. In this project, seaweed-based biomaterials bring together local knitters to honour the heritage of the Cornish gansey (a traditional fisherman’s jumper), integrating regenerative and circular design ideas into traditional local practices. 

The ganseys are seen as a symbol of identity, with every pattern specific to a place. According to folklore this enabled a lost fishermen to be identified. The 'Gwiadores' jumper is a collaboratively knitted piece, where each knitter created a wool patch in their local pattern. These were then stitched together with a seaweed based yarn and dyed pink with seaweed. 

Through conversations with local knitters, the strength of the seaweed yarn became apparent, and its suitability to reinforce areas of the jumper which receive more wear and tear was identified. Echoing the ganseys traditionally sustainable design, the seaweed thread was therefore used to reinforce an elbow patch.  

Fast-growing and carbon sequestering, seaweed requires no fresh water or arable land and supports rich underwater ecosystems. It’s an incredibly regenerative, renewable, and local resource, which plays a vital role in supporting marine biodiversity and strengthening climate resilience. 

By returning to traditional techniques and my local heritage through innovative biomaterials, Seafolk creates a dialogue between past and future. It invites the industry and consumers to rethink traditional materiality and presents a material future rooted in history, craft, community, local resources and life cycle.

From the sea. To the sea.

profile:
Jingyi Ye is a Chinese Canadian artist based in London. She holds an MA in Painting from the Royal College of Art and a BFA in Textiles from the Alberta University of the Arts (formerly ACAD). After graduating from the RCA, she joined the Turps Studio Programme to continue growing her painting practice in the UK.
Daisy’s work moves between memory, landscape, and imagination. Through semi-abstract painting, she explores feelings of space and absence, resilience and hope. Her landscapes often become a way to navigate her own multi-cultural identity and to find balance within the layered sense of belonging that comes from living between cultures.
Material plays an important part in her process. She experiments with plant dyes, ground pigments, and organic materials to build the surface of each painting, using these natural elements as a way to connect her inner world with the environment around her.
Her time living and studying in Japan, Mexico, and the UK has deeply shaped her perspective. These experiences have inspired her to explore how different cultures understand the relationship between humans and the natural world. Through her work, Daisy hopes to create a quiet dialogue between Eastern and Western sensibilities—reflecting ideas of cyclical time, memory, and place.
While at the RCA, Daisy took part in several exhibitions that highlighted her experiments with plant-based pigments and weaving. She has also been invited to speak at the RCA’s Temporal Material seminar, where she shares her ongoing research into traditional Japanese dyeing methods.
title: The Beneath, and The Beyond
material: plant dye, oil and pigment on canvas
description:
The Beneath and The Beyond explores the fragile boundary between surface and depth, visibility and concealment. The divided composition evokes a landscape in cross-section — a place where memory, matter, and time gather in layered sediments. Subtle gradations of light and texture suggest both erosion and revelation, as if something long buried briefly rises to view. This tension between decay and renewal mirrors an inner act of introspection: looking beneath appearances to uncover what endures. Through its quiet interplay of opacity and transparency, the work invites contemplation of the unseen forces that shape both the natural world and the self.

Drawing from a tranquil pond in Canada, the artist began with on-site sketches, later tracing their fluid forms onto translucent paper layered with oil paint. Pressed against the canvas, the painted surfaces leave tactile impressions — traces of contact and memory. Through delicate glazing and scumbling, depth emerges like reflection beneath water, revealing a landscape that is both seen and felt.

profile: https://ellenjingxu.com
title: I do have choices
material: Acrylic and modeling clay on canvas
description: In this series, I work with modeling clay as a living material that embodies transformation, fragility, and regeneration. The clay’s subtle shifts in texture and color reflect the continuous cycles of growth and decay within nature and the human psyche. Each form is shaped through touch and time, carrying traces of both vulnerability and resilience. Through these tactile gestures, I explore how emotional labor and embodied memory can become acts of cultural transmission,  how what is felt, remembered, or repaired within the self echoes through collective experience. The work invites viewers into a quiet space of renewal, where decay becomes a passage toward rebirth.

profile:
Nahoko Komatsu O is a contemporary artist and painter based in Japan and the UK. She uses painting to explore emotions and thoughts on various important topics including current affairs, women's rights, peace, human anatomy, and Japanese culture(Eastern philosophy, Kimono, Urushi, etc). 
Through her practice, she aims to prompt viewers to question the world around them and make a positive impact on their thoughts and emotions. She derives pleasure from the intricate and mysterious journey of creating and analysing art, and wants to share this excitement with viewers, encouraging a deep exploration of meaning and symbolism in her work.
In 2024, starting from the Royal College of Art Master of Painting with a Hospital Art Project　（Healing painting, social contribution).
Art in Hospitals, Rapidly Needed in Japan's Super-Ageing Society. The art that seeks to provide spiritual care for patients by making the facility a pleasant place to be.
She is interested in hospital art. It might have a medical meaning. It is not enough, but she also hope to contribute to society as an artist and a person of expression. In preparation for this, She studied Stanford University Medical Online’s Positive psychology: well-being Positive psychology in 2023.
Additionally, she completed a one-year hybrid programme at Tokyo University of the Arts' Diversity Care and Art in 2024-2025.
title: Pallas Athena
medium: Urushi, Egg tempera, Oil, Real Gold leaf
description: One of the 12 gods of Olympia in Greek mythology. The goddess Athena is known in Greek mythology as the goddess of Technology, Art, Strategy, and warfare. Here, I depict them as guardians details who protect everyone from disaster, suffering and illness.

profile:
Minglu Du
(b. 1998, Guiyang, China)

Minglu Du is a queer interdisciplinary artist based between Providence, USA, and Shanghai, China. Her practice spans illustration, experimental animation, games, and installation, often integrating literature and sound to create immersive, narrative-driven experiences. She frequently depicts human figures as metaphorical or surreal creatures, reflecting on social inequalities through thick, twisted forms, sharp color contrasts, and metallic textures that evoke visceral emotion.

Her work combines surreal visual language and storytelling to invite viewers into the psychological and emotional worlds of her characters. Through explorations of trauma, resilience, and empathy, she focuses on the lived realities of marginalized and diasporic communities, revealing the fragility and complexity of human relationships and social dynamics, and creating visual experiences that embody tenderness, vulnerability, and strength.
title: Apollo and Daphne
description: Apollo and Daphne is a clay-and-paper stop-motion animation that re-examines a canonical myth by revealing what is often obscured within its familiar telling. Rather than portraying Apollo’s pursuit as divine love, the work foregrounds the anxiety and coercive power embedded in a narrative structured by patriarchy. Daphne’s transformation is rendered not as transcendence but as an act of desperate self-protection, an escape that exposes the violence inherent in patriarchal desire. Through tactile materials, fragmented forms, and shifting light, the animation exposes the emotional and bodily tensions that classical narratives often romanticize, inviting reflection on fear, resistance, and the negotiations women undertake in the face of pursuit and power.

profile:
Ziyuan Wang is a visual communication designer and illustrator whose practice explores the intersection between narrative, identity, and the politics of visibility. With a focus on illness, social stigma, and emotional expression, his work transforms research-based interviews into poetic visual forms—ranging from publications and installations to interactive print experiments.

Coming from a non-traditional art background, Wang approaches visual storytelling with both emotional intuition and analytical depth. His recent work investigates how diseases like HIV and depression are metaphorically represented and socially silenced. Through participant-led archives and materials like thermosensitive ink, he invites audiences to engage not only visually, but physically—with stories that are often unheard or unseen.

Wang’s artistic language draws from the raw expressiveness of graphic novels and the cultural undercurrents of subversion. His practice lies between illustration, publishing, and critical social inquiry, aiming to create visual work that is both intimate and reflective.
title: The Unseen The Unheard
description:
The Unseen The Unheard by Ziyuan Wang is a tactile visual archive that explores empathy and ‘visibility’ within the context of illness and stigma. The work consists of three archival folders coated with heat-sensitive ink. When touched, the warmth of the viewer’s hands reveals hidden words beneath the surface. Each folder preserves the stories of those marginalized by disease. They are obscured by fear and moral narratives.

The work transforms touch into an ‘encounter’. Its interactivity depends not on technology, but on care and courage. The work does not only speak on behalf of other but also it creates a space where others can be heard. The viewer’s hand becomes the medium in this work. Only when people touch the surface of folders, the stories emerge. Here, empathy is not merely a concept, but a practice.

Rejecting dramatization, Wang adopts the position of a listener. With a restrained, documentary tone, he records and shares these voices. Through this modest archival system, he reminds us that real empathy is not pity but the courage to approach and to listen. Understanding begins when people are willing to approach.

profile:
Based in South Korea, my practice merges into the intoxicating nature of consciousness, collective, collective memory and fractured narratives of humanism. Across clay, installation and painting, I aim to interrogate hegemonic messages of current day social justice, exposing the scorched earth of cultural erasure, the iron grip of totalitarianism and the unraveling dominance of complicit silence. 
Wondering across seven nations in my formative years, I absorbed a kaleidoscope of suppressed histories and cultures - a profound privilege that shattered parochial veils. These visceral encounters ignited me to pierce through noise and propose unflinching dialogues; illuminating the shadows where humanism devours itself and the unconscious is puppeteered into submission.
title: Wrath of The Red Forst
description:
“Wrath of the Red Forest” invokes the primal animism of Hayao Miyazaki’s Princess Mononoke, paradox of the deer god, who  both quickens and unravels life. 

Its gaze is accusatory, a silent indictment of anthropocentric hubris. Nature here is not pastoral; it is a sovereign force that nurtures only to devour, its lightning-strikes as arbitrary and absolute as divine wrath. 

 This ambivalence is deliberate: the artwork refuses the sentimental ecology that frames wildfire solely as catastrophe. Instead it gives insights to the ancient role of fire as both destroyer and renewer—an ontology Indigenous fire stewards have long understood.

At its core, the work stages a confrontation: a laser-cut deer-god—its antlers fractured into crimson red—emerges from acrylic board structure, the paint layering a visceral autopsy of the forest’s own flesh.

Beneath the mythic register lies a lacerating political critique. In Canada, Indigenous communities—custodians of cultural burning practices that once modulated ecosystems—are abandoned and neglected. The government’s refusal to protect these territories is not mere oversight; it is a continuation of erasure, a slow incineration of sovereignty. The red forest, then, is both literal and metaphorical: a landscape ablaze and a body politic cauterized by indifference.

Through this diptych of creation and critique, “Wrath of the Red Forest” demands a reckoning. It asks whether we can bear to look at nature’s ferocity without flinching, and whether a nation can confront its own complicity in the ashes it pretends not to see.

profile: Yifei Cheng graduates from Royal College of Art , in Information Experience Design. In her work, she focuses on exploring the extension of human power dynamics in nature and society, as well as the development of self-consciousness under the object ideology. In addition to reflecting the quest for self-identification, her work questions established power dynamics and societal conventions. Her work explores how nature and society interact, how identity is reinterpreted in modern society, and how we discover our own place in the environment. It not only mirrors the quest for self-identification but also questions established societal conventions and power dynamics.
title: Redrum
description:
Historical overexploitation and exploitation of natural resources has often been accompanied by exploitation of labour and the environment . The quarrying of Portland Stone reconfigured the interactions between power, wealth, and land, embodying the wealth and authority brought about by colonization.
My project primarily explores the exploitation and power dynamics hidden behind limestone. It satirizes the dichotomy between the deprivation and acquisition of power during the colonial era, encouraging viewers to reconsider social identity and the politics of geological materials within a postcolonial context. Additionally, the project employs theatrical exaggeration to reveal conflicts, guiding audiences to deeply reflect on heritage and contemporary social mechanisms and examining the relationship between power structures and individual and collective identities in modern society.
Through a mechanical sculpture, the project investigates the geological and historical tensions involved in the “extraction” and “governance” of London Stone, a limestone quarried on Portland Island in the 17th century. After the catastrophic fire of 1666, the ruling class in Britain mined Portland stone to rebuild St. Paul’s Cathedral and construct symbols of authority in London. Ironically, today, Portland stone preserves the only survivor of that fire—London Stone—Ruling class at that time would hit the stone to get Power of Autonomy.

profile: Xiaoyun Ying is a Shanghai-based photographer and visual artist whose work bridges fashion, portraiture, and visual storytelling. With over seven years of experience across China and Europe, she has collaborated with brands such as YSL, Burberry, EP Yaying, and Initial, and created editorial imagery for Nision Magazine. Her recent collage works investigate the imagery of financial crisis, deconstructing economic symbols into poetic visual fragments.
title: WE ARE THE ONES WHO ARE TRULY WEALTHY
material: Fine art paper,gold leaf,archival pigment print
description: This project reconstructs the visual symbols of recurring financial crises from the eighteenth century to the present. Through a series of six mixed-media collages, it reflects different stages of trust and collapse within global financial systems. Gold leaf is used to represent the fragile illusion of prosperity, its reflective surface contrasting with the cracks and peels that reveal instability beneath. Each fragment connects historical imagery and contemporary speculation, exposing how economic value, resource extraction, and belief intertwine. The work positions financial faith as both material and metaphor, always fragile yet persistently relied upon to give value.

profile: Hi, I'm Nika! I'm an illustrator with a passion for storytelling, and a lover of general "whimsy". Some other notable themes in my work include that of community, fashion, fairytales, diversity/heritage, and childhood. I'm a major extrovert so I love working in a team, communicating, and getting to know new people, as well as new things! My only wish is to continue living my life making art that brings joy to other people :) hope you enjoy your visit into my world!
title: A Tale of Five Suits
description: This is tarot card series (also playable as classic cards) where I explored the forgotten ethnodiversity of medieval Europe, and how the history of playing cards is a culmination of so many different cultures. I did extensive research over a 6 month period documenting and tracing the history, where it travelled from 9th century China to 18th century France to become how we know them today. My cards showcased clothes and cultures of the Ottoman Turks, Tang Dynasty China, the Mamluk empire, Moorish Spain, Chandra and Deva era Bengal, and Rococo France, all chosen due to specific connections to playing cards diaspora.
size: Each card is a4, 210 x 297 mm

profile: As a Chinese artist studying abroad, I feel a deep connection to my cultural heritage and seek to infuse my work with the unique aesthetics and sensibilities of Chinese culture. In my creative practice, the articulation of ideas takes precedence over material form. I explore diverse modes of expression—ranging from digital photography and chemical development techniques to moving images and interactive installations—each serving as a medium for dialogue and connection with the audience. Rooted in my studies in the humanities and social sciences, my creative practice is shaped by a rational, analytical, and pragmatic approach. I draw inspiration from theoretical frameworks, using them as lenses to critically examine the seemingly mundane aspects of life—those implicit consensuses, default societal norms, and unchallenged perspectives that are accepted without question.
title: Time From Different Sources
categories: Camerless Photography,'levelling all things (齐物论)',Cultural Regeneration
description:
Time is not objective.
Humans often measure life using hours, minutes, seconds, years, months, and days, asserting that all creatures should conform to these temporal norms—an anthropocentric arrogance. Chinese philosopher Zhuangzi (275 B.C.) challenged this view, promoting 'levelling all things (齐物论)' to foster a non-anthropocentric ethic. In his essay 'A happy excursion (逍遥游),' Zhuangzi bases his discussion on the perception of time by living beings: 'The morning mushroom knows nothing of the noontide; the winter cicada knows nothing of the spring and autumn.' '… In ancient times, there was even one massive tree whose spring and autumn were each eight thousand years long,' highlighting 'equality' in how all things perceive time.
When I use a camera to capture the passage of time in natural organisms, there is an inevitable sense of intrusion—an imprint of human technology upon nature. This intrusion carries an implicit hierarchy, a gaze of superiority and scrutiny. In response, I turn to the ancient Van Dyke development technique, seeking a way to render time within natural forms. Insects, plants, animals, stones—these objects are placed on paper coated with Van Dyke solution, allowing light and chemistry to inscribe their presence. The interaction of the solution with sunlight produces a direct image, a silent record of time’s imprint on the natural world, revealed through the very process of development.

profile: Iris Yi‑Tyng Lin is a Taiwanese artist and researcher whose work explores memory, language, and cultural translation through tactile forms and poetic structures. Working across felt sculpture, participatory methods, and visual storytelling, she investigates how tone and communication take shape—quietly, relationally, and sometimes unresolved.
title: The shape of Tone
description:
This work represents a personal turning point—an introspective echo shaped after a series of participatory translations.
After months of sculpting others’ conversational tones, the artist returned to her own voice—not through words, but through form.

The wool carries softness, resistance, and weight. Shaped without sketches or plans, the sculpture holds what was once invisible: a memory felt but never spoken, stays like something left unsaid,
still echoing.

profile: Iris Yi‑Tyng Lin is a Taiwanese artist and researcher whose work explores memory, language, and cultural translation through tactile forms and poetic structures. Working across felt sculpture, participatory methods, and visual storytelling, she investigates how tone and communication take shape—quietly, relationally, and sometimes unresolved.
title: Kingdom of Mountain
description:
This series began as an intuitive act—softly sculpting without a concept, until the shapes revealed themselves as mountains.

Each form reflects a different emotional trace: sleeplessness, longing, fragments of land remembered.

These felted shapes are not representations, but recollections—formed through repetition, rhythm, and silence.

When placed together, they become a soft terrain of memory—an imagined kingdom.

profile: 我是聚焦装置艺术、数字艺术的创作者，以日常碎片为创作原点，用影像作为语言，在朦胧叙事中构建专属语境，传递对自我与世界的感知。曾参与“武当民间艺术数字化”展览等，都是我创作路上的印记，而我也始终以真诚的表达，探索艺术与生活的边界
title: MOSQCORE LAB
categories: 思辨设计,可穿戴交互设计,视觉叙事设计
medium: 可穿戴设备,视觉影像,技术交互
description:
本项目以蚊子 “隐藏性、渐进性、无痛传播” 的生命周期与寄生行为为核心隐喻，聚焦 “信任危机” 与 “未来技术异化”，打造思辨性科幻短片及跨媒介装置。
在创作过程中，首先通过研究蚊子各阶段特征（卵的潜伏、幼虫的积累、成虫的隐蔽传播），建立它与 “信任萌发、裂痕积累、崩塌蔓延” 的同构逻辑，随后确立 “MOSOCORE LAB” 实验室叙事框架并开发多载体表达：以培养皿、机械蚊子构建实验装置，用别针、热熔胶等材料打造行为监测类可穿戴设备，搭配品牌视觉、形象与电影分镜，形成 “装置 + 穿戴 + 影像” 的跨媒介体系。最终通过 Arduino 联动交互功能，将抽象的信任变化转化为可感知的体验。
设计理念核心是思辨未来信任困境：当信任成为濒危资源，通过技术介入使其沦为可培育、可商品化的 “培育特质”。作品以 “无痛叮咬” 隐喻技术化信任的隐蔽操控性，既揭露当今社会信任崩塌的潜伏性，也追问 “信任商品化后人类协作的本质”，让观众直观感受隐性危机，引发深层反思。

school: Harvard University / Graduate School of Design
profile: Xinyun Li is an architect and artist based in New York. After graduating from Harvard University Graduate School of Design, she has continued her architectural practice in the city. For Xinyun, architecture is a deeply emotional form of expression, a medium through which she explores and conveys her understanding of the city, life, and nature. Her work reflects a commitment to thoughtful design that resonates with both people and place, capturing the nuanced relationships between buildings, their users, and their natural surroundings. To her, design carries the weight of history while imagining what lies ahead.
title: Blueprint of Contained Lives
material: Digital Display,Print on Fine Art Paper
description: Blueprint of Contained Lives explores the condition of ordinary people’s lives today. It adopts the floor plan of the World Trade Center, a name marked by profound tragedy and loss, yet where towering structures have once again risen. In a world of relentless progress and constant change, people are driven by the demands of survival, numbly burning through their lives within the constraints of steel and concrete. Like flickering lights, they glow, dimly and brightly, illuminating the layers of buildings that seem to both shelter and consume them. What is gained and what is quietly sacrificed in our pursuit of stability, recognition, and belonging?

school: Harvard University / Graduate School of Design

For Xinyun, architecture is a deeply emotional form of expression, a medium through which she explores and conveys her understanding of the city, life, and nature. Her work reflects a commitment to thoughtful design that resonates with both people and place, capturing the nuanced relationships between buildings, their users, and their natural surroundings. title: Earthbound
material: Digital Display,Print on Fine Art Paper
description: Earthbound explores the relationship between humans and nature through the lens of dwelling. Evolving from nature, humans possess an innate instinct to live within it. Yet as our construction skills have become increasingly sophisticated, the materials we use, like steel, concrete, and glass, have made our homes ever more complex. The building process now contributes significantly to environmental degradation, further alienating us from the natural world. Earthbound seeks to reimagine a form of dwelling that is more primal and instinctual, one that meets the needs of contemporary living while drawing from and returning to nature.

profile: Ophelia Chen is a VR artist, interaction designer, and digital media practitioner whose work investigates how immersive worlds can choreograph memory, movement, and attention. Working with game engines, spatial interfaces, and 3D environments, she builds XR experiences that sit between cinema, installation, and interface—spaces where viewers become participants inside a living system rather than passive spectators.
title: Leftover Lots
description: This project began with a question sparked by the rise of autonomous vehicles: what if all the vehicles become autonomous in the future, how is the city gonna look like? The artist imagined a future where the concept of parking becomes disappeared, where cities breathe and move — no longer bound by static infrastructures but animated by a fluid, ever-shifting web of self-organizing mobility. The project explores the future of mobility, the absence of parking space, and the new urbanism.

profile: Erin is a London based Irish designer creating work surrounding themes of belief, sanctity and preciousness. Having specialised in knitted textile she has expanded her practice to include a metalworking skillset, exploring the interplay between the two. Her practice is research based, underpinned by the curation and collection of a range of material cues, and executed through intricate and involved process.
title: ‘Lambs’
description: ‘Lambs’ (2025) was made as the conclusion of ‘In Excelsis’ a body of work informed by wider conversations on faith, material culture, and consumption. Centring on Catholic acts of devotion, specifically the rite of First Holy Communion. How this inaugural moment of faith uses semiotics to express immaterial concepts through material means. Employing the ritual as a host for ideas of purity, sanctity, and penance, and how these concepts are signalled through the use of laces, white, and precious metals. The work evolved from an appreciation for the craft of lacemaking; archive visits provided an understanding of lace construction methods and a technical basis from which to translate hand construction into knit.

profile:
Yizhou Li(b.1999) is a Chinese photographer who recently graduated from London College of Communication with a master degree in Photography. His undergraduate studies in interior design cultivated his keen observation of architectural space and internal structure. While drawing, he started to get in touch with the camera and gradually tried to visualize his expression through the language of photography.

His image style is deeply influenced by Japanese ‘Conpora’ photography, which is a simple and direct way to record things in the scope of people's daily life. These images, captured by pressing the shutter without overthinking, reflect his innermost emotions and his feelings towards the outside world. By learning the techniques of the darkroom, he was able to rethink his relationship with the image while making the photographs, and in the process exploring and building his own photographic narrative.
title: North of The Rivers
description:
‘North of The Rivers' is an ongoing photography project, including 50 black &white still images which document the cities, towns and villages of northern China. The project uses the rivers as a route into the traditional cultures and lives of the people I encountered. 

In the context of the massive urban regeneration and the problem of cultural homogenisation taking place in northern China, my attempt is to reconnect with the land from the perspective of the younger generation. As my accent, personality, and habits changed with new experiences and environments, so what exactly is the 'north' for me?

North of The Rivers' could be considered as an explorative journey in search of memory and identity. As a presence that carries time and history, the river stretches and branches into murmuring or loquacious streams, where countless nostalgia stories have been told.

Consisting of river landscape and portrait images, each of them tells its own wordless narrative and pierces together the fragments of my journey; the roads I have travelled, the landscapes I have seen, and the people I have met, forming a spiritual bond between myself and the land I left a long time ago.

profile:
Medina Mammadkhanova is a London-based multimedia designer and current MA Graphic Communication Design candidate at Central Saint Martins. Originally from Baku, Azerbaijan, her practice centers on the translation of memory, emotion, and cultural history into contemporary visual and material forms. Working across publication design, tactile archiving, interactive objects, and digital experimentation, Medina explores how personal and collective histories can be reshaped through design.
Her work often takes the form of critical re-readings of existing systems, whether typographic archives, live performances, or museum classifications, to challenge how narratives are constructed, preserved, and inherited. Through methods like visual compression, sensory distortion, and material transformation, she designs tools and artefacts that make emotional or historical moments tangible and re-experiencable.
Recent projects include Methods of Translating, a visual and material archive of Aretha Franklin’s 2015 Kennedy Center Honors performance, where Medina translates the emotional language of song into engraved acrylic discs, digital line art, and layered audio experiments. This project reflects a broader recurring thread in her work: treating design as an act of cultural translation, where the past is not simply preserved but actively reshaped and returned to the present.
Medina’s practice builds on her background in editorial design and physical computing, having previously developed interactive works such as the Emotional Processor and Coping Blocks. Her work is driven by the belief that emotional and cultural legacies must be handled critically but also tenderly, occupying a space between research, making, and storytelling.
title: The Aretha Franklin CD Archive
description:
Archiving Emotion
Methods of Translating is a cross-media translation and archival reimagining of Aretha Franklin’s 2015 Kennedy Center Honors performance of “(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman.” By drawing from a moment deeply embedded in collective cultural memory, the project interrogates how emotional resonance survives when a performance is removed from the immediacy of live experience.
The original performance, available here:
Aretha Franklin - “(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman” (YouTube)
In this project, the performance becomes a site of translation, visually, materially, and emotionally. Through a methodical process of digital reduction, live footage is abstracted into engraved-like line art, each piece capturing a specific emotional moment. These line-based visuals are then translated into engraved acrylic discs, arranged in sequence to form a tactile archive. These objects merge personal memory with material reinvention.
Each disc corresponds to a key timestamp from the performance: The Stage Entrance, The First Note, The Coat Drop, The Crescendo, Carole King’s Reaction. These function as emotional markers within the archive. 
The project acts as both preservation and reinvention, treating translation as an act of return. It asks how we revisit and re-feel collective histories, how emotional heritage survives through reinterpretation, and what is lost and gained when we transform the past through contemporary design.

profile:
Elie Al Marji is a London-based Creative Director and Biodesigner whose work sits at the intersection of regenerative design, material innovation, and socio-political storytelling. Blending 20 years of creative leadership with a research-driven biodesign practice, Elie uses biology, craft, and visual communication to propose new modes of care, resistance, and cultural resilience.

His award-winning project ALWAKIA, developed through collaboration with the Francis Crick Institute, explores the cultural and ecological potential of bio-nacre; a regenerative, lab-grown material inspired by Levantine craftsmanship. Conceived in response to contemporary student activism, ALWAKIA reimagines protective gear as both a biological shield and a symbolic armour for young voices standing against injustice.

Elie is a 2025 graduate of Central Saint Martins (MA Biodesign, Distinction) and recipient of the CSM Graduate Award 2025 for ALWAKIA.
title: ALWAKIA: Bacterial-Nacre Resistance Armour
material: Bacterial nacre and olive waste leather
description:
Inspired by the violent suppression of student-led protests against genocide in Gaza, ALWAKIA (Arabic for The Protectress) responds to a world where resisting injustice is life-threatening. ALWAKIA is a statement piece of protective gear, designed for student activists who risk their bodies to amplify their voices. Crafted from bacterial nacre, a living material grown with Sporosarcina pasteurii through biomineralization, it mimics mother-of-pearl without harming ecosystems. 
In the face of extractive systems, ALWAKIA collaborates with the living: bacteria, artisans, and activists, to propose a future shaped by care, resistance, and regeneration. Offering an impact-resistant, structured armour, the project draws on endangered Levantine nacre inlay traditions, fusing cultural resilience with ecological responsibility. 
As student movements rise globally in the face of genocide, war, and ecocide, this biologically forged armour becomes both shield and symbol. It empowers a generation to protest injustice while preserving the crafts and ecosystems they fight for.

profile: Haowen (Hayley) An is a Los Angeles and Shanghai–based designer and motion artist working at the intersection of music culture, visual systems, and collective memory. With an MFA in Graphic Design from ArtCenter College of Design, she explores how sound-based subcultures can be translated into contemporary visual language.
title: RHYVRB: Club Culture & Design Movement
description:
Drawing from club culture and DJ methodology, this work treats visual elements like audio samples—layered, looped, and remixed to create feedback loops where cultural scenes echo across time. Through moving image, spatial installation, and interactive workshops, the work functions as both documentation and reactivation, capturing not just what was seen or heard, but what was felt.
RHYVRB: Club Culture & Design Movement, proposes designing through rhythm: building emotional archives of sound, place, and community that pulse, breathe, and evolve.

profile:
Maya Hoch is a multidisciplinary artist based in North London and a recent alumna of Central Saint Martins, University of the Arts London. Her practice began in childhood with a focus on life drawing and oil painting, and developed further during her foundation year at UAL, where the diagnostic pathway expanded her material understanding beyond traditional two-dimensional work.

Hoch’s practice explores the shifting relationship between the two-dimensional and three-dimensional world. Her Jewish identity as a descendant of Holocaust survivors forms a central thread throughout her work. She frequently reflects on a sense of rupture which she describes as the “missing part of me”- an imagined self tied to the Eastern European world her family escaped.

Her recent exhibition at Greatorex Gallery presented a body of work exploring the boundaries between past and present, and the spaces we inherit but can no longer return to.
title: The Łódź I Know
description:
" He would tell certain stories but if you asked him a question about those stories, he couldn’t answer. He would never deviate. He would use the same wording every time. He would tell stories about a lemonade factory that one of his relatives worked in or owned. But anything you asked about the factory he couldn’t tell you. Or he’d tell the same story about him and his father leaving synagogue and people would cut beards off the men. But if you asked where the synagogue was, or who they used to go with, he couldn’t tell you " ... After diving into my ethnic background and discovering I have no connection to the UK, I began to question who I really am. My project explores the juxtaposition between my findings from my travels back to Poland through post-Soviet brutalist architecture, and archival footage from during and before the war, in an attempt to discover what happened to my Great-Grandfather's homeland.

profile: Kai Wang is a maker with a background in Graphic Design and Visual Communication, currently developing his practice in Jewellery & Metal at the Royal College of Art. His work explores how the self emerges and withdraws within collective contexts, focusing on themes of visibility, fragility, and temporality. By translating two-dimensional thinking into three-dimensional forms, he works with paper, metal, and experimental materials to create a personal language of presence and disappearance. His practice integrates image-making, material exploration, and structural construction to reflect the unstable boundary between being seen and being overlooked.
title: Fleeting -  Linear and Chaos
description:
Kai Wang explores fleeting self-existence in crowds, observing public rhythms where he appears and disappears. Through photography and by asking strangers to “find” him, he captures brief moments of recognition that reveal the fragile balance between visibility and anonymity.

Fleeting Second translates this sensation into material form: everyday objects frozen and mirrored, then UV-printed onto aluminum, shifting from transparency to clarity. Alongside, a three-second recording of Kai on a train platform was fragmented into 120 stills, riveted into a twisting sculptural line that echoes memory’s disintegration.

profile: Kai Wang is a maker with a background in Graphic Design and Visual Communication, currently developing his practice in Jewellery & Metal at the Royal College of Art. title: Fleeting - 1/12 Second
description:
Kai Wang explores fleeting self-existence in crowds, observing public rhythms where he appears and disappears. Through photography and by asking strangers to “find” him, he captures brief moments of recognition that reveal the fragile balance between visibility and anonymity.

1/12 Second turns inward, transforming negative spaces between Kai and others within 1 second into twelve silver brooches. Layered and fragile like pages in motion, their oxidizing surfaces shift from pale gleam to dull yellow, marking time through erosion rather than a clock. Together, these works construct a spectral self-portrait—one that flickers between recognition and disappearance within the unstable space of the crowd.

profile: Haowen(Hayley) An is a Los Angeles and Shanghai–based designer and motion artist working at the intersection of music culture, visual systems, and collective memory. With an MFA in Graphic Design from ArtCenter College of Design, she explores how sound-based subcultures can be translated into contemporary visual language.
title: It's Okay to Slow Down
description: Inspired by modern burnout culture, this motion design piece traces the overlooked stages of mental health decline. Through nostalgic visual language and layered animation, it transforms invisible struggle into retrospective testimony—making present what is systematically absented in conversations around emotional labor and psychological limits. The work serves as a visual archive of absence, witnessing the gradual weight that accumulates before collapse.

profile:
I am a self-taught artist working across watercolor, digital painting, and oil. My practice is rooted in exploring the quiet interactions between nature and human life—moments where light, animals, plants, and interior spaces gently shape one another. I am drawn to scenes that evoke childhood warmth and long-buried memories: sunlight moving across a familiar room, the presence of living forms within still spaces, or the delicate blend of nature and architecture that creates a feeling of home.
Influenced by East Asian aesthetics, I use layered color and soft transitions to build contemplative atmospheres filled with intimacy, stillness, and emotional resonance. 
Through my paintings, I hope to create quiet worlds where viewers can pause, breathe, and reconnect with the tender, nostalgic moments that stay with us over time.
title: Fragments of Light
description:
This painting is based on a floral window from a Suzhou Garden. My first experience of colored light, however, happened in the West, where stained-glass windows in church cast vivid fragments across quiet interiors. When I later saw the colored light cast by a traditional Chinese lattice window, I felt a quiet crossing of memories—an unexpected moment where two parts of my life seemed to meet.
 I focused on how the window refracts and softens sunlight. The scattered light becomes both the subject and a metaphor for memory—overlapping, shifting, and shaped by different experiences. Through this work, I explore how light can bridge places, histories, and personal identity.

profile:
Yier Lu is a jewellery artist passionate about transforming emotional feelings and body-related elements into narrative jewellery.

Graduating from Central Saint Martins in Architecture and the Royal College of Art with an MA in Jewellery, she bridges traditional filigree inlay with modern techniques, exploring the dynamic relationships between people and their surroundings.


Drawing from her own experiences, Yier’s practice is inspired by the complexities of intimate relationships, using filigree and metal folding as her tools to weave stories of vulnerability, resilience, and transformation.
title: Trace of Intimacy - Self-healing
description:
It aims to uncover the harm & healing processes that happen in intimate relationships.

In this practice, I use my own experience as the concept base, filigree, and metal folding techniques to embody the process from skin injury to healing. 

Finding my expression and language to tell my story broadly. Thus, I let my childhood self know that these pains and wounds are okay, and we will find our way out.

profile: Alex Young (b. 1996, London) is a multidisciplinary artist working across sculpture, painting, sound, and installation. After studying Painting and Printmaking at the Glasgow School of Art, she completed a Master’s in Sculpture from the Royal College of Art in London. Her practice examines cycles of transformation and decay, emerging from Glasgow’s derelict industrial landscapes and the wilderness surrounding the city. Blending natural remnants with man-made materials, she investigates how time, ecology, and archaeology are embedded in matter, often through site-responsive encounters with the land. Her works draw upon autobiography, folklore and speculative fiction to explore the fragility and resilience of bodies shaped by memory and continual change.
title: Crows Descending
description: The title of this work takes inspiration from Ralph Vaughan Williams's composition 'The Lark Ascending'. The lark is a symbol of joy and daybreak, while crows are often associated with doom, death and despair. In many cultures they are psychopomps - creatures, spirits or demons who escort the deceased to the afterlife. Crows have become a symbol in my work for fear, liminal beings, and altered states of consciousness.

profile: Alex Young (b. 1996, London) is a multidisciplinary artist working across sculpture, painting, sound, and installation. After studying Painting and Printmaking at the Glasgow School of Art, she completed a Master’s in Sculpture from the Royal College of Art in London. title: Wishing Tree
description: Wishing trees are found throughout the British Isles, often near sacred wells or waters. To this day people visit them in the hopes of curing themselves of disease. Reflecting on feelings of hope and shame, I created my own wishing tree through the alchemy of reclaimed wood, gold leaf, cast bronze pills, recycled cotton yarn and a medical bracelet.

title: Shame Flute
description: Medieval music and folklore led me to the shame flute, an instrument of torture and public humiliation. This flute was made from a hollow bronze cast of an oak branch, a tree symbolising endurance, fertility and wisdom, with a spiral copper ring to be worn around the neck.

profile: Xiwen Wang is a textile designer from China, specializing in weave and material innovation. She explores the sensory and emotional dimensions of textiles through inventive combinations of color and material. Her work often incorporates techniques such as jacquard, floats, and pom-poms to create fabrics with rich tactility and three-dimensionality. Deeply interested in the relationship between color and human well-being, she aims to uncover the emotional resonance within textile experiences. Looking ahead, Xiwen strives to continuously push the boundaries of woven materials and techniques, seeking new possibilities that merge creativity with functionality.
title: Tactile View
description:
This project explores how color can be experienced beyond vision—through scent, touch, and material interaction—by using natural materials as a sensory medium. It focuses on the synesthetic perception of color, aiming to create emotional and bodily responses through multisensory textile design.

Through researching psychological, cultural, and sensory associations of natural colors, I will build a “color–scent–touch” mapping system. Materials such as silk, cotton, paper yarn, and wool will be used to translate each color into a unique sensory combination—expressing its emotional tone, texture, and temperature. The outcome will be a multisensory color coding system applicable to textile design.

The project responds to contemporary interests in experiential design, sensory diversity, and nature-based materials. Final outcomes will include a sensory swatch book, emotional textiles, and color installations—suitable for exhibitions, therapy spaces, and educational tools—redefining how we perceive and connect with color through textiles.

profile:
Born in Shanghai in the 1960s, Shu Yong received his formal training at Shandong Academy of Art and Design and later pursued advanced studies at the Graduate School of the Chinese National Academy of Arts. With a professional background spanning years in art and design, he has executed nearly a hundred design projects of varying scales. Throughout this period, he has consistently engaged in interdisciplinary creative practice, producing poetry, painting, calligraphy, and sculpture. Their expressive spontaneity and stylistic versatility characterize his works.
Shu Yong's creations have been featured in over ten prominent national art and culture publications, including "Art Observation", "Art Panorama", "Chinese Painting & Calligraphy News", "Gallery", "Chinese Calligraphy", "Modern Calligraphy", "An Anthology of 300 Modern Poems", "Huaxia Poetry News", and "Selected Poems of Guangdong". He has held and participated in numerous solo and group exhibitions across China, with works held in private collections in the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Japan, South Korea, and other countries.
title: The "When Will Our Deliverance Come?" Series
description:
Created in 2008, this significant nine-panel polyptych serves as a critical witness to the accelerated, and often disordered, urban redevelopment in China. The title, quoting a classical lament from the Book of Documents, elevates the subject from a specific social issue to a timeless cry for justice and belonging.

The artist's strategy is one of profound intimacy and confrontation. Each panel zeroes in on the human face, employing a controlled, figurative painting technique to articulate a spectrum of emotions—resignation, anxiety, and silent inquiry—through the depiction of the subjects' eyes. This orchestration of gazes forms the core of the work, directly implicating the viewer and questioning the very definition of "progress." The series thus transcends social commentary, standing as a poignant meditation on displacement and the universal right to an "anchored existence."

profile:
I’m a London-based multidisciplinary designer, my practice centres around themes of belonging, intergenerational connection, and the quiet beauty of everyday life. I work across documentary, photography, and participatory storytelling—using observation and conversation to create space for overlooked voices.

Through my work, I aim to foster empathy and understanding, connecting people across cultures, generations, and lived experiences. I’m passionate about socially engaged, community-based projects and always open to thoughtful collaborations.
title: Stories from Wuyi Centre
description:
Stories from Wuyi Centre is a documentary that explores the everyday realities and emotional connections within the British Chinese community. Through shared meals, ping pong games, intergenerational care, and casual conversation, the film offers a gentle but powerful challenge to common stereotypes—especially the idea that Chinese communities are only visible during festivals or
in Chinatown.

Instead, it highlights quiet resilience and day-to-day life, giving space to voices often unheard in mainstream narratives. The work encourages reflection on identity, belonging, and shared futures, contributing to more inclusive, empathetic, and human-centred forms of visual storytelling and community research.

profile: Visual artist, painter and print maker, my practice is a sensory and philosophical inquiry into presence, memory and subjectivity. I work with voice recordings, personal archives and my own mirror image to explore making as a haptic and open ended negotiation. Using auto ethnographic methods, I incorporate the voices of my mother, myself and my grown-up children to engage with transgenerational listening and emotional inheritance. Rooted in phenomenology and post aesthetic thinking, my work repositions the self as a constellation of shared experiences that are partial, relational and in constant transformation.
title: Mo Mháthair Ériu (My Mother, Ériu)
description:
Mo Mháthair, Ériu began as a self-portrait drawn in marker while listening to recordings of my mother reciting poetry in the final months of her life. The raw, child-like lines echo the rhythm of her voice and the memory of her reading Irish fables and stories of Irish warrior queens to us as children. These vocal traces became a way to return, to culture, mythology, and matriarchal histories, while also moving forward through the act of drawing.
Inspired by David Hockney’s Xerox works and their playful questioning of whether a copy can become an original, I developed the laser-print drawing. By layering, rotating, and superimposing the autoethnographic portrait with scans of paint experiments also made while listening to my mother, exploring how reproduction can generate new presence.The print becomes a site where memory, gesture, and voice recombine, an event rather than an image resonating with Heidegger’s notion of art as a mode of being. It explores how returns, to voice, to myth, to the maternal open pathways toward the future as I navigate grief and my own creativity .
The title, Mo Mháthair, Ériu (My Mother, Ériu), invokes the Irish mythical mother-figure who embodies the land itself. The portrait becomes a transtemporal meeting point, an echo and a return, where personal memory entwines with cultural mythology, continually reshaping itself in the present.

profile: Claire Yuri Song is a Los Angeles-based Korean Brazilian American artist whose multidisciplinary practice consists of paintings, sculptures, and installations. She is a BFA graduate in Illustration from ArtCenter College of Design. Her work revolves around her personal life, specifically around her struggles with her ideas and relationship with religion.
title: You of Little Faith
description: An intimate crisis of faith in an age of secular comfort

profile: Li Tang Chen is an interactive designer and artist whose practice explores the shifting relationship between humans and intelligent systems. His work blends physical computing, speculative design, and storytelling to question how technology redefines power, control, and emotion.
title: IDomestication
description: Set in a world ruled by artificial intelligence, IDomestication envisions a future in which humans are no longer free but are domesticated within monitored zones. The installation takes the form of an ID classification system that symbolizes how unseen authority assigns value, determining one’s living space, expiration, and recyclability. Through sensor-based interaction and algorithmic logic, the work reflects on how systems of control, disguised as efficiency, gradually domesticate humanity itself, blurring the boundary between observer and subject, master and the domesticated.

profile: Li Tang Chen is an interactive designer and artist whose practice explores the shifting relationship between humans and intelligent systems. His work blends physical computing, speculative design, and storytelling to question how technology redefines power, control, and emotion.
title: FoodCourt
description:
Team with Randeep Satish and Chaehyeon (Iris) Kang

FoodCourt is an interactive dining table that responds to object placement with cultural sounds and visuals. As users “feed” different plates, rhythmic audio from various countries blends in real time, visualizing distance or cultural fusion.

title: Echo, echo
categories: Symbol systems, folk paranormal phenomena, field investigation
medium: Fake documentaries, community involvement and workshops
description: This project is based on folk supernatural field legends and folk beliefs in unknown events, with unknown alien creatures and crop circles as the information context. During this period, we visited the Crop Circle Museum, designed and produced aliens, and brought them into local communities and public environments in London for interaction. In the context of crop circles, we have studied a large number of cases related to symbols and energy, and firmly believe that there are many unknown information and energy transmission channels beyond the scope that current technology can confirm. It can be seen from the crop circle information records that thermal testing in the natural crop circle range shows that the reality of the instrument changes regularly at different locations.Looking at the patterns of crop circles over the years, we can see that they show amazing regularity. Combined with patterns and mandalas from various cultures, we believe that crop circles are most likely the language system of alien creatures to communicate with us in this way. Therefore, we began to sort out the basic symbols contained in it, and brought it into the community for research, gradually generating a new language composed of pure geometric patterns. During the generation process, we also bring into the community to guide people to speak, write or draw their own words in this language.

profile:
Sumin Joo is a visual development artist whose work explores the intersection of myth, cultural memory, and speculative world building. Specializing in background design and digital painting, she draws inspiration from architecture, traditions, and ritual aesthetics to construct immersive environments grounded in narrative depth. Her practice blends research based visual development with storytelling, examining how histories are preserved and reinterpreted across generations.

Working across digital illustration, concept art, and environment design, Joo builds worlds that question power, identity, and the fluidity of cultural inheritance. Her projects often engage with themes of collective memory, mythic regeneration, and the politics of history, using visual development as a form of contemporary archive making.
title: Fallen Sky
description:
Fallen Sky draws from North African culture, aesthetics, and architecture to reimagine a desert civilization shaped by fractured memory and rewritten myth. Inspired by architectural forms, textile motifs, and ritual design traditions of the region, the work constructs an empire whose visual language is both ancient and futurist. Within this world, fox demigods, elite floating hammams, and ornate winged machines exist as curated remnants of a manipulated past.

Set against this backdrop, the story follows a young rebel from the abandoned poor fox tribes, who steals a sacred fruit and inadvertently awakens the wrath of the god once responsible for dividing her people. Her act becomes a catalyst for confronting the myths upheld by the elites, revealing buried histories and challenging the narratives that shaped the world’s hierarchies. As she journeys across scorched badlands and sacred ruins, she seeks not only survival, but the possibility of returning life to the dying desert.

The piece examines how history is selectively preserved by those in power, contrasting the glorified narratives of the ruling class with the suppressed memories of the oppressed. By merging North African inspired cultural codes with contemporary digital painting, Fallen Sky positions world building as a form of archival practice; one that bridges folklore, cultural inheritance, and speculative futurism.

Through this interplay of myth, story, and reconstruction, the work reflects on how societies continually reshape their past. Fallen Sky invites viewers to consider how looking back is not a pause but a transformation: a way of rewriting futures through the echoes of memory.

profile: Born Chinese and lived in China for the first 15 years of my life, I settled in Canada for the past decade; now, I find myself resettling in China once again. As someone whose identity is not always consistent and often marginalized by mainstream socio-political narratives, I'm drawn to themes and fragments that channel "a presence of the absence", or a "hauntology" of my personal life.
title: Echo(lalia)
description:
Entitled Echolalia, this vellum zine experiments with the materiality of language and reflects the three gestures that have shaped my experience of learning English as a second language: collecting, combining, and echoing. 

Echolalia—often defined as the seemingly meaningless repetition of words spoken by infants—resonates deeply with my own linguistic journey: each time a native speaker corrected my pronunciation, I internalized and recalibrated the “proper” sound, layering new forms of speech over earlier ones. Drawing on Daniel Heller-Roazen’s insight that language acquisition hinges on “a kind of linguistic infantile amnesia,” quoting his Echolalias: On the forgetting of language (2008, 11), I consider this work an exploration of how becoming a “native speaker” requires both remembering and forgetting, both echoing and overwriting.

Writing poems can feel intimidating for a second-language speaker, so I turned to found poetry as a way of reconstructing meaning from what already exists. I sourced phrases from used books on critical theory, environmental science and art—texts written in a kind of “public language.” Through cutting, rearranging, and recontextualizing their words, I transform these authoritative voices into something more intimate: a provisional, personal language that emerges through repetition and fragmentation.

Each clipped word or phrase is steeped in oil, rendering the paper translucent so that the text on both sides seeps through. This creates a palimpsestic field where front and back echo one another. Verses are no longer contained by a single page or a fixed orientation; instead, meanings return unexpectedly when pages are overlaid, reversed, or read through. What appears is a haunting interplay of legible and illegible layers—a re-emergence of echoes that were once lost.

In this way, this zine situates language not as a stable repository of meaning, but as something that continuously haunts, repeats, and remakes itself.

major: Critical Practice in Fashion Media and Communication
profile: Cloud Dare is a Queer multidisciplinary creative working from London in community organisation regarding climate emergency. Their history as professional tailor provided unique insight into human-object relationships whilst undertaking Critical Practice for Fashion Media and Communications at London College of Fashion for their undergraduate study. The culmination of their BA research is in Scavenger-Crafting as an actionable methodology for forging relationship-oriented modes of living within a dying planet. Their work activating this field branches broadly, seeping into as many access points as possible, including performance art, academic text, primary school teaching, Queer event organisation, poetry, film and Drag.
title: I am you, and you are me
description:
You Are Me… And I Am You is a moving collage: a self-portrait constructed through accumulation of digital objects. The work seeks to evoke ‘melting’ between experiential and material reality—using distorted sound, layered image, and spoken word to dissolve ideological boundaries between self and environment. I am a collage of all that precedes me; these skin borders cannot contain me; I am large, I contain multitudes.

The piece draws from three deeply intimate archival strata.
First, footage from my parents’ wedding is intercut with fragments from completed and abandoned short films, forming an inherited visual DNA that bleeds into my own creative attempts.

Second, my camera roll—detachable hippocampus. Much of this digital hoard has vanished beyond this film: a failure to upload to any Cloud, and reminder that my techno-limbs are as losable as memory itself. These flickering images warp the layers beneath, pulling the viewer into a near-hypnotic attempt to see through the noise. This fragmentation reflects not only how coherence is strained under algorithmic media onslaught, but how we reproduce this distortion in our personal archives. Upon owning the tools to manufacture media, the boundary between the self and the media produced evaporated.

Third, diary entries written while ‘coming to’—from consumer-comfort-centric simulacrum to a deeper critique of capitalist individualism shaped through white supremacy. As I grappled with Descartes’ legacy of severing thought from matter, I recognised the profound loneliness shaping my life was not personal failure but systemic design. My writings grieve a self who watched their life on an internal television, striving to reunite soul with matter, and reach for solidarity in a system that profits from isolation.

The collage culminates in two soundscapes: an unsettling static that repels the viewer, followed by slow, elegiac chords that pull them back—inviting them to confront their own estrangement and unravel with me.

profile:
Meisen Jamir  is a multidisciplinary textile designer based in London, currently studying for an MA in Textiles at the Royal College of Art. Originally from Nagaland in Northeast India, she holds a BA in Textile Design from the National Institute of Design, Ahmedabad. Her practice is grounded in surface design and mixed media, shaped by a strong connection to making, material exploration, and cultural research.

Meisen’s work is informed by traditional practices, everyday observations, and an interest in how objects and materials carry stories across time. With a hands-on approach, she often works with techniques such as dyeing, stitching, and printing, using them not only as aesthetic tools but as methods of reflection and storytelling.

Meisen sees textiles as a space for dialogue — between memory and material, tradition and innovation — and uses her practice to explore the quiet yet powerful ways design can connect people, places, and time.
title: the beetles
description:
The Masters collection, "The Beetles," draws on my childhood fascination with beetles and reimagines them through the visual language of Indian chintz. The project explores beetles as symbols of resilience, adaptation, and overlooked beauty. Through playful reinterpretation, it positions textiles as a dialogue between tradition and innovation, encouraging viewers to look closer at hidden details.

The collection combines traditional and digital techniques, producing two types of samples: tactile surfaces created with unconventional materials using traditional methods, and contemporary surface designs inspired by heritage crafts. Together, these pieces reflect a balance of memory, materiality, and creative experimentation
